properties.name: 01/05/07 - Kittens stuffed up drain and left to die
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineLL11 1NFANIMAL rescue workers say four tiny kittens, cruelly dumped in a Wrexham drain, were close to death when they were found. The kittens, just eights days old, were rescued from behind the old register office building in the town centre. They were wedged into a drain, and found by a man working late, before being taken to Capricorn Animal Rescue, Padeswood, Flintshire. The centre\'s owner, Sheila Stewart, said: "Luckily, the man who found them was one of our members. When they first came in it was touch-and-go whether we could save them, but now it looks like they will pull through. "This is just a terrible thing to do. There is no way these kittens could have been born in the drain, they must have been dumped. It is so cruel. We are constantly publicising the work we do, and people know they do not have to do this kind of thing." To read the full story go to: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2842780

properties.name: 01/05/07 - Life of hell on Flintshire estate
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FAMILY left terrified when the home next door was gutted in an arson attack say they are living in fear after a brick was thrown through their front window. Just after 1am on Sunday, Sandra Davies\' son was arriving home at Albert Avenue, Flint, from working at McDonald\'s, when the house brick was thrown, covering him in glass. Just a few hours later, at about 11pm, Sandra says about 15 cars on the street were drenched in paint. "My son and my ex-husband were there until five taking the shards out of the window frame to put up the board again," said Sandra, who lives with her 24-year-old daughter, sons aged 17 and 15, and three-year-old grandson. "The window was smashed 18 months ago, and things have been thrown at it since. My landlady has said because it\'s been broken before and keeps being targeted she\'s going to keep the board up. It\'s really depressing. "At first I thought it might have been personal, but I\'ve realised it\'s not because it\'s happening all over the street." For more on this story follow the link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2843064

properties.name: 01/05/07 - Smokers saved from window ledge trap
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO young women had to be rescued from the ledge of a Chester pub after climbing out of a window for a cigarette. Cheshire Fire and Rescue Service received a call at about 4.30 this morning from a member of the public after walking past the George and Dragon, Liverpool Road, and seeing the women, both in their mid-20s, trapped on the three-foot ledge. Firefighter Nick Shaw, of Chester Fire Station, said: "They climbed out of the window for a cigarette but it shut behind them so they waited for a passer-by to walk past to raise the alarm." To read the full story follow the link http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2843097

properties.name: 01/05/07 Parents vow to fight school closure
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline CH3 5BA Parents and governors say the fight to save their Chester city centre school is far from over.They were commenting after county councillors met yesterday and recommended consultations on closing Boughton St Paul\'s Infant and Nursery School.The plan, as part of the county council\'s controversial Transforming Learning Communities (TLC) agenda, is for the school to shut in the summer of 2008, with the children being dispersed into neighbouring schools.Parents have fought strongly against the plans since they were announced officially in February, mounting a huge campaign to \'support our school\'.Now, after a School Planning Panel meeting went against them yesterday, parents have reacted in shock and disappointment.To read the full story follow the link:http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2843481

properties.name: 01/06/07 - Gateway landmark decision delayed
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DECISION on which design has won the competition to be Wrexham\'s "Angel of the North" has been postponed until next week. The announcement had been expected today, June 1. More than 100 votes have been cast at Wrexham Arts Centre on the designs for the "iconic" landmark sculpture in Chirk. Project leaders have submitted a bid to the Big Lottery fund for £800,000 to £1,000,000 to pay for the structure.

properties.name: 01/06/07 - Special help in fight to save threatened horse sanctuary
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineKIND-hearted special school pupils from the South of England have come to the aid of a horse sanctuary which is threatened with closure. A group of children at Chailey Heritage School, a day and residential special school for children with complex physical disabilities and associated learning problems in East Sussex, read about the plight of the HACK sanctuary, Llay, on the Evening Leader website last month. The sanctuary has looked after distressed, neglected and badly-treated horses and ponies since 1992, but a funding crisis means its future is bleak. HACK relies entirely on donations from the public and charitable trusts, as well as its own fundraising activities, and was recently rocked by news that one of its major backers could no longer offer it financial support. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2922498

properties.name: 02/05/07 - Arsonists cause hillside inferno
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFIRE chiefs have issued a stark warning after crews battled a deliberately-started gorse blaze in Flintshire three times. North Wales Fire and Rescue Service says lives are being put at risk and tremendous pressure is being put on resources after a month of unseasonably warm weather during which there has been almost no rainfall. The comment came after three separate fires on Moel y Crio, Rhesycae. Firefighters from Holywell were first called to the scene at 10.10pm on Monday (April 30), with a crew from Mold called to deal with the second incident at 4.25am on Tuesday. By 2.20pm the same day, firefighters from Holywell, Flint and Corwen were drafted in to tackle a third blaze, which spread to cover a staggering 2,500 sq m of gorse, finally leaving the scene at 5.30pm. To read the full story go to http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2848070

properties.name: 02/05/07 - Chester Jets face closure over cash crisis
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER Jets basketball team must raise £90,000 by July or go out of business. The club is on the verge of folding and will be forced to close if suitable sponsorship is not found. In fact, the Jets could be defunct as early as the end of this month unless a business plan is produced proving they are able to fulfil next season\'s fixtures. The British Basketball League has set a Thursday, May 31, deadline for the club to prove it has the necessary finances to continue to compete in the league. In a last-ditch attempt to keep the club afloat a crisis meeting has been called by the Jets\' new nine-man management team. To read the full story follow the link http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2848240

properties.name: 02/07/07 - City's terror scare
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE in Chester are stepping up patrols in the city to calm public fears after the weekend\'s terrorist attacks. Cheshire Constabulary is responding to terrorism incidents in London and Glasgow, by increasing high visibility patrols aimed at reassuring the public. Officers say although there is no specific intelligence singling out Chester as a target, the heightened fears of the public mean police are being extra vigilant with suspicious-looking vehicles and people. On Friday, Chester city centre was embroiled in the middle of a bomb scare. Cheshire police confirmed an area on Vicars Lane, near the Visitors Centre, was cordoned off at about 6.15pm, after a suitcase was found unattended at a bus stop. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2996815

properties.name: 02/07/07 - Cottage roof set on fire
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA THATCHED roof cottage was set on fire in the early hours of Saturday morning. Firefighters were called to the unoccupied property on Chester Road, Buckley at 2.25am. Two crews extinguished an area of the flaming roof, before the fire spread to the rest of the building. “The cause was deliberate ignition by persons unknown,” said a North Wales Fire and Rescue spokesman. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2996710

properties.name: 02/07/07 - TV celebrity helps open zoo’s new orangutan realm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTELEVISION personality Nick Knowles visited Chester Zoo, to open a new sanctuary for critically endangered Sumatran and Bornean orangutans. The zoo\'s £3.5 million Realm of the Red Ape, Europe\'s largest orangutan enclosure, was officially open on Saturday. The opening marks the end of two years work developing the old enclosures into a state-of-the-art tropical home for the orangutans and a number of other Indonesian forest animals, including reptiles, birds, mammals. The enclosure also includes about 2,000 plants. Nick recently returned from a trip filming in Borneo, where he came face-to-face with orangutans to discover more about their plight in the wild. The film is for the BBC\'s Saving Planet Earth series, in which a number of different celebrities lend their support to threatened species. Nick said: "Having been to Borneo and seen the orangutans\' natural habitat and the rate at which it\'s disappearing, breeding programmes and the work being done at Chester Zoo become more important everyday." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2997359

properties.name: 02/08/07 - Boy, 10, held over robbery
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA BOY of 10 has been held over an alleged armed robbery with a Stanley knife. Police have confirmed the youngster was arrested in the Groesfan area of Penycae on suspicion of holding the knife to the chest of another boy and stealing his go-kart, as well as possession of an offensive weapon. The 10-year-old, who, police say is from Rhos, has been bailed pending further inquiries. The incident, which is alleged to have taken place at 8pm on Tuesday, was raised at a neighbourhood police meeting in Rhos last night, and has caused widespread concern in the community. The alleged victim is believed to have been aged 11. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3080071

properties.name: 02/08/07 - CCTV cameras demand after armed robbery at house
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCALLS have been made for CCTV cameras in a village after an armed robbery. On Sunday night, intruders beat a man with a crowbar during a robbery at his home. Police are now hunting three men who forced their way into the home of the Hawarden pub landlord, assaulted him, and stole a large quantity of cash and jewellery. They then fled in a stolen silver Vauxhall Cavalier, which was later found burned out. Officers were called to the house, on The Wigdale, shortly after 11pm on Sunday and deployed the force helicopter to conduct a sweep of the surrounding area, but the men remain at large. A North Wales Police spokesman said: "Shortly after 11pm on Sunday we were alerted after men forced their way into a house in Hawarden. "The three men, who were carrying weapons, threatened the occupants of the house and assaulted a man with what is believed to be a crowbar. "They then left the house with a large quantity of cash and jewellery." Alyn and Deeside MP Mark Tami has now called for CCTV to be installed in the centre of Hawarden. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3080421

properties.name: 02/08/07 - Full honours for airman
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE funeral of young Flintshire airman killed in southern Iraq takes place next week with full military honours. Peter McFerran, 24, of Connah\'s Quay, a senior aircraftsman in the No 1 Squadron Royal Air Force Regiment, was killed with SAC Matthew Caulwell and SAC Christopher Dunsmore on Thursday, July 19. They were resting between shifts protecting aircraft operating from Basra Airport from the threat of militia when the building they were in came under rocket attack. Peter\'s body and those of his colleagues SAC Caulwell and SAC Dunsmore were repatriated last Wednesday when they flew into RAF Lyneham. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3080176

properties.name: 02/08/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - We're losing our fight town image
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSERIOUS violent crime has dropped dramatically in Wrexham. New figures released to the Leader show that the town has seen serious incidents fall by a third in the last year, with the total number of violent crimes recorded also dropping, bucking a regional trend. Police say recent measures to tackle booze-fuelled violence in our streets are now bearing fruit. Town centre inspector Chris Beasley has put the improvement down to early intervention by officers, stopping potential troublemakers going on to attack people during their nights out. During the last year there were 543 violent crimes in Wrexham, a reduction of 1.8 per cent on the previous year. But strikingly, more serious offences have been reduced, including grievous bodliy harm with intent, down by 33 per cent, and grievous bodily harm without intent falling by 42 per cent, which Insp Beasley said bore out his belief in the power of stepping in early. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3080157

properties.name: 03/04/07 - Town chaos looms as car parks close
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePARKING chaos is expected in Holywell next week as foundation work begins on a new superstore, closing three long-stay car parks on the site. Car parking space is already at a premium in the town centre and many business owners and staff who use the three car parks for all-day parking are upset. Town centre manager Medwyn Roberts said the council had planned to have a replacement car park completed by now but it would not now be ready until August or September. For the full story follow this link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2850672

properties.name: 03/05/07 - Vote of no confidence in police chief
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA UNANIMOUS vote of no confidence in the North Wales police chief was last night passed in Flintshire. Connah\'s Quay town councillors censured Chief Constable Richard Brunstrom and North Wales Police Authority following claims of "poor leadership, negligent behaviour and crazy spending priorities". A statement read out to the meeting by Cllr Arthur Hannah claimed Mr Brunstrom and the police authority had grossly mismanaged the police force by "wasting huge amounts of money on gimmicks, witch-hunts and disastrous computer systems" and removing police from the streets. Follow this link for the full story: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2851844

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Armed police will patrol Wrexham
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineARMED police are to patrol Wrexham\'s key transport hubs in a bid to reassure the public over the terror threat facing Britain. In the wake of the failed car bomb attempts in London and the attack on Glasgow airport this weekend, police have moved quickly to monitor the situation in North Wales. The arrest yesterday of a man in Liverpool, as well as those of a man and a woman on the M6 in Cheshire, have heightened fears plotters could be operating in the region. Police will be at rail and bus stations, as well as pubs and other crowded areas. In a statement, the force said: "North Wales Police are taking prudent measures in light of the heightened security alert following the attacks in London and Glasgow. "In addition to the armed officers at the main port of Holyhead, highly visible armed officers will be on patrol at a number of train and bus stations, and also in other locations across the force area which may be vulnerable. "These include areas where large numbers of people may gather, as well as licensed premises. Checks along the main arterial routes within North Wales will also continue." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999100

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Chester's soldier killed in mortar blast
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA CHESTER man described as the "finest soldier of his generation" was killed in action in southern Afghanistan. Capt Sean Dolan, from 1st Battalion, The Worcestershire and Sherwood Foresters, died while on an operation with US and Afghan troops in Helmand province on Saturday. The 40-year-old, originally from the West Midlands but based in Chester, was observing Taliban fighters from a vantage point when he was killed by a mortar round. Tributes have been paid today to Capt Dolan, who was killed in the Sangin Valley area during an operation to maintain pressure on the Taliban. The Ministry of Defence described him as "undoubtedly regarded by all who had the honour of serving with him as the finest soldier of his generation". http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999708

properties.name: 03/07/07 - College fundraising a record-breaker
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTAFF and students at Deeside College are celebrating raising a record £32,138 for Marie Curie Cancer Care. After 18 months of fundraising, they formally presented the cheque at a celebration event at the college. The funds have been raised through a variety of events, including sponsored walks, the purchase of daffodils for lost loved ones, cake stalls, raffles, dragon boat racing and a casino night. One of the highlights of the year included catering lecturer Chris Griffiths\' 100-mile trek through Peru. Chris joined 32 others from across the UK to raise a combined total of more than £100,000 for Marie Curie. Chris alone raised £3,700. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999118

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Lottery winner revealed
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA LIVERPOOL fan from Wrexham has been celebrating on the terraces at his favourite football ground, Anfield, after \'kopping\' a £891,682 share of the Lotto jackpot. Marcus Lewis, 41, says the lottery win will definitely change his life. The railway engineer has supported Liverpool FC all his life and a season ticket for the \'Mighty Reds\' is now top of his \'premier league\' shopping list. Marcus, who is married to Amanda, 40, and has four children - David, 20, Jonathan ,17, Alice,15, and Lucy, 13 - only realised he had netted the jackpot after he took the ticket into a nearby shop to be checked. Marcus added: "This is something everyone dreams of. The machine told the shop assistant that it was a substantial amount of money. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999866

properties.name: 03/07/07 - VIP opening as zoo leads way to save rare apes
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineEUROPE\'S largest orangutan enclosure has opened at Chester Zoo. TV presenter Nick Knowles was on hand to officially open the Realm of the Red Ape – a new £3.5m home for critically endangered Sumatran and Bornean orangutans. The official opening marks the end of two years\' work developing the old enclosures into a state-of-the-art tropical home for the orangutans and a number of other Indonesian forest animals, including reptiles, birds, and mammals. The enclosure includes some 2,000 plants. Nick said: "Having been to Borneo and seen the orangutan\'s natural habitat and the rate at which it\'s disappearing, breeding programmes and the work being done at Chester Zoo become more important every day." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2997540

properties.name: 03/08/07 - All set for Roodee fun day
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline ALL areas of the Roodee in Chester will be open for the annual Sunday Fun Day, say the organisers. Nearly 150 horses have been entered for the races and gates to the Open Course will be open from 8am and to the Paddock from 11.30am. Richard Thomas, chief executive of Chester Racecourse, said: "The Roodee desperately needed the recent drier weather for the family entertainment to take place. "It\'s really fantastic that all aspects of the Sunday Fun Day are going ahead and we are looking forward to people who live in the surrounding area celebrating the arrival of summer by bringing their picnics and gazebos for a great day out." Clerk of the course Ed Gretton said: "We are really looking forward to Sunday. "The going is likely to continue to dry out between now and Sunday as summer arrives at last." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3084500

properties.name: 03/08/07 - Eisteddfod all set to draw thousands
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE curtain will finally go up tonight on the much-anticipated National Eisteddfod being held in Flintshire. Tonight (aUGUST 3) will see a spectacular opening ceremony and concert with the main field opening early tomorrow to welcome the thousands of visitors who will descend on the county. The National Eisteddfod is the biggest celebration of Welsh culture, language and dance in Europe and the county is bracing itself for huge crowds and hopefully, good weather. Betsan Williams, from the Eisteddfod organising team, said: "We\'re finally getting a summer and the sun has had an effect on the field and dried it. The weather forecast is promising ideal weather and we\'ve laid a stone path around the field. "It promises to be amazing." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3085191

properties.name: 03/08/07 - Firm fined after worker broke legs
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM frozen food company has been told to pay nearly £34,000 in fines and costs following two incidents – one leaving a worker with two broken legs and another which left an employee badly injured. Pann Krisp, based on Wrexham Industrial Estate said "lessons had been learnt" and that it "deeply regretted both instances". The company, employing about 250 workers, pleaded guilty to the two breaches of the Health and Safety Act, which occurred within 11 days of each other in July, 2005. The first case, heard at Wrexham Magistrates Court, happened on July 3 when Patrick Brindley, 53, was trapped when his truck fell between a loading bay and a temporary refrigerated trailer. Simon Parrington,who was prosecuting for the Health and Safety Executive, said Mr Brindley received back injuries after falling in a standing position. Mr Parrington told the court the company had failed to resolve problems with air pressure levels which, when at the correct level, ensured access to the refrigerated store via "bridges", even though workers had expressed concerns before the incident. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3084272

properties.name: 03/08/07 - Fury as hoodies torch cadet centre
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineYOUNG army cadets are facing a bleak future after a gang of arsonists senselessly torched their headquarters. The vandals broke into the Army Cadet Hut on Coast Road in Mostyn on Wednesday night and set fire to the store room, destroying all the furniture and equipment. The group, who were dressed in hooded sweatshirts, jumped the seven foot barbed wire fence and forced open the building\'s fire exit. Once inside, they started a fire in the rear of the building, which has just been refurbished and relaunched to offer local youths activities and training. As the fire started to spread through the hut, Cadet officer Colin Hughes arrived to carry out maintenance and caught the teens in the act. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3085182

properties.name: 03/08/07 - Plans for a new county town move a step closer
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePlans for a new town in Flintshire moved a step closer after councillors agreed to hold a summit meeting to discuss the issue. Councillors have taken the recent flooding in other parts of the UK as a warning and say they need to find a long-term solution to the over-development of existing communities. There are also serious concerns there is not sufficient infrastructure to support the 7,400 homes that are due to be built by 2010, outlined in the council\'s draft Unitary Development Plan (UDP). Flint councillor Alex Aldridge wants to identify virgin land south of the A55 which is not on a flood plain and where houses can be designed and built from scratch, incorporating a range of modern, eco-friendly features. Cllr Aldridge, who proposed the motion at a meeting of the full council, wants to put a stop to large housing developments being "bolted on" to existing communities. He said: "This could cripple the drainage infrastructure of local communities, which could result in the sort of devastating flooding seen in Gloucestershire. "This year, Flintshire has experienced some flooding due to the severe weather but not on the scale of seven years ago, when parts of the county were under water. Bolt-ons also could result in areas losing their identity." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3082421

properties.name: 03/08/07 - Woman leapt from burning home
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA 19-YEAR-OLD girl was forced to jump from the bedroom window of a burning Chester house early today – into a neighbour\'s arms. Her mother was then rescued by another neighbour, who got a ladder to help her down from the bedroom window, in Allington Place, Handbridge. City firefighters say the two women were saved because they had a working smoke alarm in place. Watch manager Anthony Jones said the property was severely damaged by the blaze, with 50 per cent smoke damage on both floors. He said: "The smoke alarm saved their lives after they were alerted by it. They were also saved by a neighbourly action. "Emotions were definitely running high after this incident." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3085237

properties.name: 04/05/07 - All change in Wrexham
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineJOHN Marek has been ousted as AM for Wrexham. The Independent was beaten into second place in the Assembly election by his former secretary, Labour\'s Lesley Griffiths. Her Clwyd South colleague, Karen Sinclair, fought off a strong swing to the Conservatives to hold on to her seat. Dr Marek, who represented Wrexham since the Assembly\'s inception in 1999, had been hoping to fight off the challenge of Mrs Griffiths, who he beat at the last election by 973 votes. This time, however, she turned the tables to reclaim the town seat with a majority of 1,250. For the full story follow this link http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2854966

properties.name: 04/06/07 - Condom concern in alley
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOUNCILLORS have expressed their concerns after a discovery of a used condom in a popular alleyway in Rhos. The issue was raised at the latest meeting of Rhos Community Council. The meeting heard the condom was found in an alley leading to Maes y Ficerdy. A discussion took place regarding the possibility of closing the alley. After the meeting, councillor for Ponciau, Paul Pemberton, said it was unlikely the alley could be closed because of rights of way issues. He explained the condom was found during an environmental audit carried out by the area\'s police community safety officer. He said: "The audit sees the officer go around the village and look at issues such as where children have been drinking or where people have been fly-tipping. "The audit found one used condom and it was mentioned at the meeting that perhaps the alley could be closed but as I understand it, it would be a problem because of rights of way." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2923312

properties.name: 04/06/07 - Rescue centre's appeal for support over move
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN animal rescue centre is calling for the community to support its proposed move to a new location with better facilities. For the past 24 years, volunteers from the Capricorn Animal Rescue, in Padeswood, have worked tirelessly to care for animals of all shapes and sizes, but the sanctuary needs to move. The group\'s founder and secretary, Sheila Stewart, said they made an offer on a smallholding at Moor Lane, Higher Kinnerton, which has been accepted. Sheila said they have now applied to Flintshire Council for a change of use from agriculture to an animal sanctuary, as the property has no close neighbours and is on a no-through road. "It is an ideal location for Capricorn Animal Rescue\'s new sanctuary," she said. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2922847

properties.name: 04/06/07 - Top-level talks over Airbus plans to cut costs across the board
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAIRBUS is putting its proposed cost-cutting measures out to consultation. The planemaker, which employs about 7,000 people at its Broughton plant, is opening discussions at national level on the Power8 plan to turn the company round. Once these consultations are finalised, Airbus hopes to shed enough jobs through voluntary departures over a four-year period, to cover the losses incurred by delays to the A380 production. It is thought up to 800 will be lost in Broughton through natural wastage. The company, owned by aerospace giant EADS, is also considering selling a number of their sites or working in partnership with other companies. After comprehensive discussions on the Power8 programme during Airbus European Works Council (ECA) meetings, Airbus is now starting negotiations at national level with its social partners, with regular reviews at ECA level to continue. These negotiations are to analyse in more details the reasons and consequences of the plan and also to agree on the appropriate social measures to be applied in line with local regulations and agreements in order to achieve the overhead reduction targets set in Power8. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2922848

properties.name: 04/06/07 - £2,000 reward to catch street attack gang
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA COMPANY is offering a £2,000 reward for finding out who attacked a man as he walked home after a night out. Paul Segar , from Hoole, suffered a fractured jaw and cuts after being attacked on Saturday, May 26, as he made his way home from a night out with friends. The 51-year-old had been out drinking in Chester with his son, Darren, friend Sean Collister and Sean\'s girlfriend, and was walking home alone through Boughton, where he was confronted by a group of four or five men on a car park by Boughton St Paul\'s School. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2925841

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Lights, cameras, action as city named top location
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER has been named location of the month by a panel of top TV and film producers. The historic city has always been a firm favourite with tourists, but now it is starting to catch the attention of film and TV producers. Over the last 18 months Cheshire has seen a massive 49 per cent increase in the number of filming days taking place, and often its Chester which is top of their list of locations. Interest in the area has been so marked Chester has now been named July\'s Location of the Month by Northwest Vision + Media, which works on behalf of the TV, film, radio and digital content industries. One production that filmed in the city was BBC1\'s Lillies, which recorded at the City Baths. The Victorian pool provided the perfect backdrop to Lilies\' period story, set in the 1920s. More recently, a new advert for Crunchy Nut Cornflakes took to the banks of the River Dee, to film a boat race with a difference. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002397

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Muggers strike as woman leaves hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A WOMAN who had just received hospital treatment was pushed on to her back before having her money stolen by two youths. The robbery happened in the grounds of the Countess of Chester hospital at about 2.50pm on Saturday. The 30-year-old woman was walking towards a newsagent on Liverpool Road when she was approached from behind by two youths wearing blue hoodies. She had just taken some money from her pocket and the youths tried to snatch the money from her grip. As she resisted, the youths pushed her on to her back before snatching her money and running away towards the city. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002268

properties.name: 04/07/07 - PICTURE AND VIDEO SPECIAL - Castle Cement tower blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA selection of images sent in by readers during the dramatic fire at the Padeswood plant. Thanks to all our readers who sent in their images, videos and comments to digitalnews@nwn.co.uk To see the pictures and videos click the following link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002198

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Robber demanded cash after breaking into victims home
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN was threatened by a knife-wielding intruder in her bedroom. The 44-year-old was in bed at her home on Karen Way, Great Sutton, Ellesmere Port, at about 11pm on on Sunday, when a teenage boy entered the premises. He went upstairs, threatened her with a long-bladed kitchen knife, and demanded money. Anna Galloway, of Cheshire Constabulary, said: "He then searched the premises before stealing a quantity of cash and property. He left through the front door." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3003890

properties.name: 04/07/07 - £100,000 revamp for library
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA VILLAGE library is to undergo a facelift after nearly £100,000 in grant funding was secured. Rhos Library has been picked out from a number of projects nationwide to benefit from cash from the Welsh Assembly. The money will be spent to improve the building\'s facilities, in particular for community groups, schools and young adults and disabled people. Clwyd South AM, Karen Sinclair welcomed the news, which she said would mean a "significant" makeover for the library. She said: "Libraries are vital for members of our community who can\'t access the very latest up-to-date technology in their own homes." Ms Sinclair added that children, parents with young families and pensioners would all benefit from the new facilities on offer thanks to the investment. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3000668

properties.name: 05/05/07 - Councillors back £500,000 plans to strengthen bridge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA ROAD bridge is to be strengthened at a cost of £500,000. Councillors have given their backing to work to strengthen Pont Felin Puleston, which carries the A5152 Wrexham to Rhostyllen road over the River Clywedog. They also agreed to authorise compulsory purchase powers to acquire land required to carry out the scheme. A report to Wrexham Council\'s executive board said the work was long overdue, and added: "Negotiations with owners of land required for the scheme commenced in September 1996 but the scheme fell through owing to lack of funding. Recent attempts to resurrect the scheme have been halted because some of the land required is owned by the National Trust and cannot be sold to the council unless the council uses its statutory powers to acquire it." Councillors were told that if no objections to the compulsory purchase order were lodged the work could start next summer. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3003855

properties.name: 05/06/07 - Eagles Meadow enters new phase
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCONSTRUCTION work at the Eagles Meadow development in Wrexham is entering a new phase. The piling process has now finished at the multi-million pound shopping, leisure and residential complex, and steelwork is now being put in place. The flyover has now been completely dismantled, and workers are all set to start on the steelwork at the old AVIS site, the area next to St George\'s Crescent. Work on the development is progressing on schedule, and is expected to be completed by autumn, 2008. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2927720

properties.name: 05/06/07 - Man admits £339,000 fraud at hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A FORMER employee has admitted transferring thousands of pounds from the Countess of Chester Hospital into a personal bank account. Michael Buckley, of Plantation Drive, Ellesmere Port, pleaded guilty at a Chester Crown Court plea and case management hearing yesterday to fraud by abuse of position. Buckley, 38, worked at the hospital as head of payable accounts and on February 15 transferred £339,100 of health trust money into a personal bank account. He then left the UK for Bangkok in Thailand, and only returned after family members phoned to ask what was happening as the police were looking for him. Christopher Moss, defending, said Buckley was of previous good character and was expecting to be made redundant at the time of the theft. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2928458

properties.name: 05/06/07 - Public inquiry starts into cockle fishing
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A PUBLIC inquiry into the future of cockling on the Dee Estuary begins today. The Environment Agency Wales (EAW) has applied to DEFRA and the Welsh Assembly to restrict the number of fisherman using the Estuary in a bid to protect the stocks. The public inquiry will start today and is expected to finish on Friday with a decision due to be announced later in the summer. An Environment Agency spokesman said: "We have applied to DEFRA and the Welsh Assembly for a Regulating Order under Section 1 of the Sea Fisheries (Shellfish) Act 1967. "This will give us powers to create a sustainable cockle industry on the Dee Estuary while protecting stocks and the natural environment." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2926569

properties.name: 05/06/07 - Racecourse glory days re-lived as ex-boss makes emotional return
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FATHER and son team have reflected on Wrexham FC\'s 1970s glory days on an emotional return to The Racecourse. Ex-Reds manager John Neal and son David were back at the historic ground on a rare visit to the town for a promotional day held by the club, and relived some proud memories. For David, who now lives in America, the day was a particularly poignant occasion. A member of the Wrexham youth team that produced, among others, Joey Jones and Mickey Thomas, David never made the grade as a professional at the club. While dad John has gone down in Racecourse folklore as the man who guided Wrexham to FA Cup and European Cup Winners\' Cup quarter-finals, David quit the game at an early age, and was left wondering if he would ever step out on the turf again. He was given the opportunity on Sunday when he turned out for the fans\' website Red Passion\'s team at the club\'s Red for a Day promotion. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2925875

properties.name: 05/06/07 - Villagers left with no phones for six weeks
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineRESIDENTS living in a remote rural community say they have been cut off from society because they have been without phones for two weeks. About 20 homes in the quiet village of Rhosesmor, near Holywell, have had no working phone lines for a fortnight – and it could be more than a month before they are fixed. On May 23, a lorry going down a single track lane pulled down a telephone line connecting the Wern area of the village. The families, and a number of elderly residents, have now been cut off and say they feel isolated. Celene Williams, of Wern Road, said: "My daughter is in a wheelchair, as is the 87 year-old man next door. "There are a lot of elderly people and people with mobility problems in this community and they have no means of contacting their friends and relatives. "It\'s already quite remote here and we are feeling isolated." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2928341

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Airman making miracle recovery after 12 month coma
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM airman who survived a mystery roadside incident, which left him in a coma for months, is battling back Greg Vickers was left fighting for his life in Borras Park, in September, 2005. He suffered serious head injuries and spent several months in a coma. A partial recovery meant he was able to return home in December, and the rate of his progress since then has been a revelation. And now keen sportsman Greg is even back at the crease, playing cricket under the supervision of coach Paul Cartwright. Paul said: "In the six weeks I have been working with Greg, I have seen a big difference. He is coming on all the time and it is amazing to see. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006712

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Boy racers driving flat dwellers to distraction
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA GROUP of angry residents whose lives are blighted by boy racers on the streets of Chester have started a petition in the hope of blitzing the problem. People living in the Newtown flats in Chester, who are tired of being kept awake by the antics of the boy racers, are hoping the petition will raise awareness of the situation to the police. Tony McCabe, of St Anne\'s flats, told the Leader that cars have been gathering in the Gorse Stacks car park late at night and then racing around the roads, leaving residents suffering sleepless nights. He said: "These boy racers are using Chester as if it was a Monaco Grand Prix. From about 10pm onwards they park in the car park before the gates are locked and then they do full circuits of the dual carriageway." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3004540

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Carer Bill prepares for life without his 'marvellous girl'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DOTING husband who wrote an inspiring booklet about caring for his wife through her Alzheimer\'s illness is facing life without her. Since 2004, Bill Tuer has raised more than £4,000 for the Flintshire branch of the Alzheimer\'s Society by selling his booklet Caring for Marjorie. After suffering with dementia for more than 15 years, Marjorie died a fortnight ago aged 90. Bill, 86, who lives in Eryrys, Mold, first met Marjorie when he was 14-years-old and the son of the head gamekeeper on the Reynold\'s family Iscoyd Park estate, near Whitchurch. At the time, Marjorie was 17 and was the lady of the house\'s personal maid. After Bill became Marjorie\'s full-time carer a support carer suggested he write some of his memories down as a therapeutic way of keeping his mind off things and soon he had written his memoirs A Prince Among Poachers. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006633

properties.name: 05/07/07 - City set for 'war of the buses'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA "WAR on the buses" is set to break out across Chester following the historic sale of Chester City Transport. On Monday evening, Chester City Council completed the sale of its bus stock to First Group, Britain\'s largest bus operator. It was heralded as the deal that would secure the future of bus services in the city, but has now been overshadowed by rival company Arriva\'s plans to launch an extra 18 bus services an hour from the city centre bus exchange, which is already operating above capacity. Arriva\'s proposals to introduce an additional 12 services an hour to Blacon and a further six an hour to Saughall follow a high-profile court battle, which was initiated by the city council\'s former cabinet. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3008569

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Doctor's plea: 'Dont't let bombers tarnish our image'
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE head of a top doctors\' group has moved to reassure the public after eight doctors or people linked to the NHS were arrested over the London and Glasgow car bombs. Dr Jay Nankani, of the Hillcrest Surgery, Holt Road, Wrexham, is chairman of the GP forum of the British International Doctors Association. He said people should not allow the arrests to tarnish the image of his profession. "I, and the group, would like to condemn any form of terrorism, and the activities of those involved in London and Glasgow," he said. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3004711

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Environment Agency to investigate Castle blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCASTLE Cement has moved to reassure residents it\'s business as usual at the Padeswood plant following a blaze that took 14 hours to bring under control. Firefighters were called to the plant at 12.14pm on Tuesday to deal with a fire on a conveyer belt. Initially, two crews from Deeside, a crew from Buckley, a crew from Wrexham, the aerial ladder platform, environmental protection unit and incident command unit from Wrexham were at the scene. Just after 3.30pm exhausted firefighters called for relief and crews from Flint, Johnstown, Ruthin and St Asaph and the incident command unit from Colwyn Bay were drafted in. The aerial ladder platform from Wrexham returned to the scene at 7.09pm and at 7.37pm and 8.23pm crews from Wrexham and Deeside replaced those from Flint, Johnstown, Ruthin and St Asaph. The last crew left the scene at 2:20am yesterday and North Wales Fire and Rescue Service are investigating the cause of the fire. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006583

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Work starts on Eisteddfod tent with 30 days to go
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE countdown has finally begun to one of the biggest events in Flintshire\'s history with just 30 days left until the National Eisteddfod begins. Construction of the National Eisteddfod\'s main pavilion on the Pentrehobyn Estate commenced yesterday, with electric winches hauling giant metal support legs into place. Chief executive of the National Eisteddfod, Elfed Roberts, was in Mold yesterday to witness the giant pavilion being erected and said it was \'quite an exciting sight to see\'. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3007378

properties.name: 06/06/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - New prison for county?
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLINTSHIRE could be home to a new prison after calls were made to build a facility with 500 places in north Wales. In a report published today, a group of MPs who sit on the Welsh Affairs Committee has called for new facilities to be built to combat overcrowding and allow offenders to be closer to home. The report highlighted the lack of custodial facilities in North and Mid Wales and was prompted by concerns nearly half of all Welsh offenders sentenced by local courts are held in English prisons. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2931443

properties.name: 06/06/07 - Man jailed after throwing puppy against wall
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has been jailed for beating his ex-partner in front of his two children and throwing her puppy against a concrete wall and kicking it. Keith Anthony Davies, of Sycamore Drive, Lache, appeared for trial at Chester, Ellesmere Port and Neston magistrates\' Court, where he was found guilty. He was sentenced to 20 weeks in prison. Magistrates\' chairman Mr Evans said: "There is no other appropriate way to deal with the offence of assault on a young mother in front of young children and the attack on the animal." Davies, 26, denied assault by beating Emma Atkinson, of Crescent Road, Ellesmere Port, on April 4, and cruelly abusing an animal on the same day. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2932065

properties.name: 06/06/07 - Mum's anguish as baby faces leg amputation
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA HEARTBROKEN mother has today spoken of her agony after being told her baby daughter will have to undergo a leg amputation. Rebecca Hayward, 38, of Wrexham is mother to four boys, and 16-month-old Madison, who was born with the extremely rare "disorganisation-like syndrome". She has a number of conditions, one of which is a leg that has no knee muscle, two tibias, two feet and nine toes. Madison is due to have the leg amputated in September. Her mother said: "She is so happy you wouldn\'t know there was anything wrong with her but she should be walking by now. She gets frustrated when she climbs on the sofa and wants to jump down but she can\'t. "People comment on her leg in the street which is devastating. I tell them she is having it amputated and they feel terrible then. She has surprised us all by crawling because we didn\'t think she would be able to. I cried when she crawled for the first time. "This is a very rare syndrome and I have been told Madison is the first baby in the Wrexham area to be born with this condition in 25 years." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2930835

properties.name: 06/07/07 - War of words over claims city walls are a danger to public
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA furious war of words has broken out over the state of Chester\'s historic walls, amid claims they are unsafe to the public. Liberal Democrat councillor Jean Evans claims a report from Chester City Council\'s design and conservation manager Howard Dickenson refutes claims made by local Conservatives before the election that the walls were a threat to public safety. Cllr Evans said the Conservatives had claimed there was something wrong with the walls and that the last administration was pretending there wasn\'t. She said: "We realised there was something wrong which needed to be fixed and started working for that to be done. "The Conservatives are claiming there is a threat to public safety, and the walls could become unsafe, but the city does not have control where they are moving – where they are adjoined to the Grosvenor Hotel car park – as it lies on someone else\'s land and they are reluctant to have work done." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3008273

properties.name: 07/05/07 - Dowser's quest to map holy wells
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MASTER dowser is inviting people to help him \'chart new territory\' with an expedition to trace Flintshire\'s Holy wells. Specialist diviner Peter Taylor, of Sunnyridge, Mold, is taking part in a tour of North Flintshire\'s Dowsing Hotspots, including including Winnifred\'s Well, Dyserth waterfalls and the Gop in Trelawnyd. A dowsing professional, with over 20 years experience discovering untapped resources, Peter was recently voted the county\'s top Deviser. For the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2856037

properties.name: 07/05/07 - Man plunges from City Walls
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN is recovering in hospital after falling off the City Walls.The man is thought to have mistaken the height of the drop on the other side before he jumped over and plummeted to the ground.Chester firefighters were called to the base of the King Charles Tower, off Frodsham Street, at about 5.40am on Saturday.Firefighter Phil Wilding said: "The fire service had to assist the ambulance service by using a spinal board in case the man had spinal injuries."To read the full story follow the link below:http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/viewarticle.aspx?sectionid=5768&articleid=2858396

properties.name: 07/06/05 - Pensioner exposed himself in city cafe
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline AN ELDERLY man has been given a suspended prison sentence and placed on the Sex Offenders\' Register for intentionally exposing himself to waitresses in a cafe. Marcus Alexander Tyrrell, of Garden Lane, Chester, had denied the charge and also denied assaulting the manager of Hattie\'s Tea Shop in Rufus Court where the incident took place on January 28, and using threatening or abusive words or behaviour. He had been found guilty at an earlier trial at Chester, Ellesmere Port and Neston Magistrates Court and returned to court yesterday for sentence. Tyrrell, 72, was given 20 weeks in custody, suspended for two years, placed on a supervision order for two years and was put on the Sex Offenders\' Register for seven years. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2937296

properties.name: 07/06/07 - Anger over 'bullying' council letter about hedge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM Council has been accused of bullying elderly, vulnerable residents over an uncut hedge. One resident of Bryn Way in Ruabon – 83-year-old Irene Wright – said she was reduced to tears when she received a letter from the council ordering her to cut the hedge which runs at the back of her house. The letter said if the hedge was not trimmed within 14 days the council may carry out the work and reclaim the costs incurred. The council has since issued an apology for any distress caused by the letter and says it will be working with residents to resolve the issue. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2935140

properties.name: 07/06/07 - Historic pub 'will not be demolished'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORRIED fans of Wrexham Football Club have been reassured by developers that a historic pub will not be demolished. A petition was put together to make sure the 150-year-old Turf Hotel, which is in the shadow of The Racecourse, was safeguarded during the proposed redevelopment of the Kop Stand end of the ground. Fans feared the historic pub would be lost as part of the development which will see the building of a huge apartment complex, shops and a new stand. It is believed Wrexham FC was founded at the Turf Hotel – which is the only pub in the world attached to an international ground – and for years, fans were able to watch matches from the pub\'s balcony. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2935923

properties.name: 07/06/07 - Jail threat to man who failed to pay mislaid library books fine
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM man has been warned he could face jail if he does not pay fines originally imposed for not returning two library books. Nathaniel Reid, 21, of Bryn Issa Road, Brynteg, appeared in court in Wrexham, and was sentenced to pay £120 by magistrates for having not paid the original fines for failing to return the books in 2005. The books were taken out from a library in Whitchurch, where Nathaniel was living at the time. He said: "One was an idiot\'s guide to music, and the other was a book about guitars. "I have lived in Brynteg for the last 12 years, apart from the spell I had in Whitchurch and then six months in Buckinghamshire just after that. With all the moving around I was doing I mislaid them." Nathaniel said when he returned to the house in Whitchurch from Buckinghamshire, he found warning letters from Shropshire County Council and was summoned to court in Market Drayton in September 2005. The council was awarded payment, and since then Nathaniel has been pursued by the courts. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2935074

properties.name: 08/05/-7 - Singer holds all the aces after Racecourse fightback
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA SINGER who entertained fans before Wrexham\'s dramatic win over Boston on Saturday looks set for stardom. Ian Dunn, known as Ace, sang on The Racecourse pitch before the Reds\' relegation decider against the Lincolnshire side. His producer and manager, former Coedpoeth man Richard Goss, said the appearance was the next step in the 24-year-old\'s blossoming career. Richard said: "The song went down well and we have had a lot of interest in it. It\'s called Fighting Back and is perfect for a football club. For more on this story follwo the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2860868

properties.name: 08/05/07 - Police pledge to clear up estate
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE have warned they will be taking tough action on a trouble-hit estate as more residents complain of anti-social behaviour and criminal damage. Albert Avenue resident Sandra Davies last week described life as "hell" on the Flint street, saying her window had been broken and that 15 people were out scrubbing their cars clean of paint the weekend before last. Other residents have contacted the Leader, confirming there is trouble on the part of the street between Chester Road and Prince of Wales Avenue. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2860033

properties.name: 08/05/07 - Probe after garage blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN INVESTIGATION has been launched after fire ripped through garage premises late last night (May 7). Five crews were called out to the blaze in Pentre, near Chirk at about 11.55pm. Three crews from Wrexham and crews from Chirk and Llangollen spent more than three hours tackling the fire at the Smithy Service Station, Whitehurst, which is next door to a tyre depot. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2859667

properties.name: 09/05/07 - Family flees house inferno
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A FAMILY of six had to be evacuated as a fire raged in their Chester home this morning. Firefighters arrived at a property on Highfield Road, Blacon, to find an intense fire burning in the lounge and conservatory after receiving a call just before 6am. The family evacuated the building safely, but it is believed the fire could have been burning for two to three hours. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2863695

properties.name: 09/05/07 - Force's tribute to gunned down officer
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 09/05/07 - Workers held at gunpoint in store robbery
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA SHOP assistant held at gunpoint was hurt and a \'substantial\' amount of money was stolen in a terrifying armed raid at an off-licence. The raid happened on Monday, at Bargain Booze in Brunswick Road, Buckley, when staff were closing up for the night at 10.25. Two people, believed to be men, forced their way into the shop. One is believed to have been armed with a gun and the other with a crowbar. For the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2862853

properties.name: 09/07/07 - Cement boss hits back in storm over factory fire
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE manager of a much-maligned cement plant has hit out at its critics in the wake of a fire. The blaze at Castle Cement\'s Padeswood factory last Tuesday took 14 hours to extinguish and sparked criticism from residents and councillors. But in a letter to the Leader, works general manager Mark Cox slams "people intent on castigating the site at every opportunity to further their own aims". He writes: "Contrary to the impression many people appear to have of the incident the fire did not occur on the tower or the chimney of the kiln. It was caused by a conveyor belt resulting in a \'flue\' effect on the tower. "Although the visual impact was obviously noticed, the safety and environmental impact was actually very small. "The site was not evacuated, there was no fall out, and there was no impact to the water course. I have instigated an internal enquiry to ascertain the root cause of the fire." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014525

properties.name: 09/07/07 - Crackdown in taxi plate row
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTAXI drivers operating in Wrexham with plates from another town could face legal action as part of a major crackdown. Officers have warned they will come down hard on Hackney cab drivers from Wrexham travelling to Oswestry to buy their plates at considerably less cost. The council has revealed taxi drivers are getting their hackney plates cheaper in Oswestry and operating as private hire taxis in Wrexham. Licensing standards in Oswestry are different to Wrexham, which has led to council officers in Wrexham to take a \'serious look\' at the situation and the law. In Oswestry, after the first year, drivers only have to renew their licence, which includes a criminal records bureau (CRB) check, every three years, whereas Wrexham Council rules mean they must renew their licence once a year. At £132, a Wrexham hackney cab licence is £33 more than an Oswestry one, priced at £99. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014321

properties.name: 09/07/07 - Do you know these men?
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FLINT police officer wants to speak to the two men pictured as part of an investigation into damage caused to a Mini car. It follows reports that a car was damaged while parked in a car park opposite Richard Heights, Flint. It is estimated the damage will cost hundreds of pounds to repair. The incident happened at approximately 1.20am on Saturday, May 5. Anyone with an information as to their identity should contact PC 2520 Carla Green at Flint on 0845 6071002 or call Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014611

properties.name: 09/07/07 - Mass protest call by A494 campaigners
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline ROAD protesters are calling for a mass demonstration at a key meeting. The A494 Aston Hill public inquiry pre-meeting is being held tomorrow, and campaigners say it is vital as many people as possible attend to show the strength of objection to the plans. Local action groups based in Aston Hill, Queensferry, Aston Mead, Hawarden, Ewloe Green, and Aston Park are working on their Statements of Evidence for the public inquiry, which is due to begin in September. The pre-meeting will lay out the format and timetable for the public inquiry and schedule any site visits which may be required. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014612

properties.name: 09/07/07 - Tornado hits Flintshire
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLINTSHIRE is experiencing the kind of freak weather seen only once in a lifetime, including a spectacular tornado. This photograph – taken by Leader photographer Rick Matthews from Hilbre Island – shows the tornado over the Mostyn/Ffynnongroyw area at noon yesterday (July 8). At the same time people living in the area reported either extremely heavy rain or hail. Met Office spokesman Sancha Lancaster says the phenomenon is described as a funnel cloud until it touches the ground, when it becomes a tornado and causes destruction. Bagillt Community Council chairman Mike Reece reported a minute of heavy rain in the village at the time and Ffynnongroyw county councillor Dolly Banks said there was very heavy hail there and heard there was particularly torrential rain in Mostyn. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014839

properties.name: 10/05/07 - Beauty spot booze ban
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePolice pledge summer-long crackdown at Meadows. An alcohol exclusion zone has been introduced at a Chester beauty spot to curb anti-social behaviour. It covers the Meadows, alongside the River Dee, after complaints about litter left by under-age drinkers. Police have also launched a monitoring operation. PC Paul Taylor, of the Chester Outer Neighbourhood Policing Unit, said: "An operation has been put in place to combat anti-social behaviour in the Meadows and surrounding areas, and will be running throughout the summer months. "In the first week, one adult male was arrested for theft of alcohol and a juvenile for assault. Police will be taking positive action over people identified committing offences in these areas." For the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2869142

properties.name: 10/05/07 - Countdown to National Eisteddfod begins
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE final countdown to one of the biggest events in Flintshire\'s history has begun. Just 86 days remain until the 2007 National Eisteddfod comes to Mold, and yesterday groundwork began on transforming the Pentrehobyn Estate, on the outskirts of the town, into a venue capable of hosting Wales\' premier cultural festival. More than 150,000 people are expected to descend on the town for the week-long festival, which runs from August 4-11. For more on this story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2867132

properties.name: 10/05/07 - Man died after being turned away from hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MAN who attended hospital four times, claiming to be unwell, suffered a massive stroke in a police cell and later died, an inquest heard. John Gwynfryn Jones, known as Gwyn, was first taken to Wrexham Maelor Hospital after his sister, Annette Edge, and her husband, called an ambulance on December 17 after the 45-year-old fell at his flat at St Mary\'s Close, Chirk. But after failing to be admitted he was taken into protective police custody ahead of an appointment with a psychiatrist the next day. The Flint inquest heard that although he died in hospital on December 21 it was technically in "police custody". To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2867869

properties.name: 10/05/07 - New officers to pound region's streets
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 10/05/07 - Rain hits crowds at Roodee
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineRAIN hit the opening day of Chester Racecourse\'s May festival, with attendance figures down on last year. The three-day event got under way at the Roodee yesterday with 17,600 present for the Chester Cup, the showpiece race of the first day. More than 19,000 attended the corresponding meeting last year. Richard Thomas, chief executive of Chester Racecourse, blamed the persistent showers yesterday afternoon for the disappointing turnout. To read the full story use the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2867276

properties.name: 10/05/07 - What's going on with the 'glass slug'?
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTories urged to reveal timescale for ditching council office plan PRESSURE is now being brought to bear on victorious Tory councillors to kill off Chester\'s "glass slug". Margaret Parker, new Conservative leader in Chester, is adamant the proposed new city council offices on Gorse Stacks will not be built and plans to meet managers of ING, the proposed developer, next week. Nearly a week after the Tories made seven gains and swept to control of the city council for the first time in 20 years, Cllr Parker said: "We are working on scrapping the plans for the new council building at the moment. "We have to have a meeting with ING that will take place next week and hopefully the plans will be scrapped. We will stop it, but I would also like to point out it will not affect the Northgate Development." To read the full story follow the link: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2869166

properties.name: 10/07/07 - Council housing boss steps down in stock sell-off row
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA HOUSING officer at the centre of a major row over Flintshire Council\'s housing stock has resigned. Gerald Davies was singled out for criticism by the Joint Trade Union Committee last week, after he sent a letter to tenants asking them to refuse permission for unions to be given their addresses. The union wanted the addresses so they could explain what might happen if they vote to transfer the council’s housing stock out of the authority’s hands and into that of a registered social landlord. The union reacted with anger, accusing Mr Davies of trying to ‘gag’ them in their bid to warn the thousands of council tenants about the ‘dangers’ of selling off their homes. Mr Davies’ letter asked tenants to tick a box if they did not wish their details to be passed onto a ‘third party’. The incident prompted the leader of Flintshire Council, Cllr Aaron Shotton, to step in, saying he shared the union’s concerns and called an emergency meeting of senior officials on Friday. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3017040

properties.name: 10/08/07 - Eisteddfod focus on youngsters who take their own lives
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSHOCKING statistics unveiled by world-famous tenor Rhys Meirion reveal that 74 young people committed suicide in Flintshire in the past five years alone. The opera star was the invited guest at a reception held by PAPYRUS Cymru at the Flintshire Local Health Board\'s (FLHB) stand at the National Eisteddfod on Wednesday. Rhys joined parents from Flintshire whose children had taken their own lives in promoting PAPYRUS\' helpline. "As a parent I can\'t begin to imagine the horror these people have endured and I\'m full of admiration for the fact that they\'ve picked themselves up and done something positive so that parents like me don\'t have to go through the same thing," said Rhys. "I was shocked by these statistics and hadn\'t realised that so many children locally and across Wales go to these dark places and kill themselves." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3100730

properties.name: 10/08/07 - WATCH THE VIDEO: Council to outlaw 'tombstoning' from bridge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA HARD-hitting new law is to be introduced to stop youngsters risking their lives by jumping from a bridge into a river. The bridge in Llangollen is a notorious spot for the practice, known as "tombstoning", with youngsters taking their lives into their hands by plunging into the River Dee below. The problem has now taken on a new hi-tech dimension, with footage of some of the dangerous acts being uploaded onto the video sharing website, Youtube. In the most recent, added just this week, and claiming to show events from last weekend, two young men jump from the bridge, despite pleas from passers-by to think twice. One even jumps backwards into the water, before another, described as a "random passerby", joins the two in the water. As well as the dangers posed to their own safety, there are concerns over groups of youths who gather on the bridge to watch the jumpers and are drinking and being abusive to passers-by. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3101994

properties.name: 10/08/07 - WATCH THE VIDEO: Council to outlaw 'tombstoning' from bridge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA HARD-hitting new law is to be introduced to stop youngsters risking their lives by jumping from a bridge into a river. The bridge in Llangollen is a notorious spot for the practice, known as "tombstoning", with youngsters taking their lives into their hands by plunging into the River Dee below. The problem has now taken on a new hi-tech dimension, with footage of some of the dangerous acts being uploaded onto the video sharing website, Youtube. In the most recent, added just this week, and claiming to show events from last weekend, two young men jump from the bridge, despite pleas from passers-by to think twice. One even jumps backwards into the water, before another, described as a "random passerby", joins the two in the water. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3101994

properties.name: 10/08/07 - Welsh language group target Tesco for their 'tokenistic' attitude
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMORE than 20 demonstrators sat blocking the entrance to the Tesco store in Mold yesterday, before 100 others protested at the National Eisteddfod claiming the store shows a lack of commitment towards a bilingual Wales. Members of Welsh language society, Cymdeithas yr Iaith, who claim the store\'s efforts towards bilingualism are tokenistic, congregated at the supermarket at 2pm to demand more of the supermarket chain. "We\'re here to show our total dissatisfaction with Tesco\'s tokenistic attitude," said the society\'s chairman, Hywel Griffiths. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3101757

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Flasher shocked woman posting letter
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN had a shock when she tried to post an item at a house in Buckley only to feel the occupant\'s manhood through the letterbox. Darren Wilcock, 36, of Powell Road in Buckley, admitted exposing himself by placing his genitals into the letter box of his front door just as the woman was making the delivery. But Wilcock claimed his actions were not directed at the woman and said a friend had previously played such a prank on him. He believed it was his friend who was approaching his home, and decided to do the same to him. Magistrates were told he had not realised there was a woman on the other side of the door. However, while on bail for that offence, Wilcock admitted committing a further offence when he pulled up his jacket and exposed his genitals to two women who were passing in a car. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943140

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Inquiry calls for cockle fishermen to be restricted to 50 per year
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOCKLE fishing on the Dee Estuary is likely to be restricted to 50 fishermen per year. A four-day public inquiry held in Chester last week looking into the problem of falling cockle stocks in the estuary heard from local cockle fishermen, environmentalists and representatives from the Environment Agency Wales (EAW). Alan Winstone, environment manager at EAW, said: "The inquiry was very constructive and very useful. Everyone had the opportunity to put forward their views and we had a good representation from the fishermen and I think everyone\'s found it a very beneficial process." He said the inquiry found a Regulatory Order was needed to develop a viable and sustainable fishery and to avoid the boom and bust situation that exists at the moment, which has seen cockle stocks fall. Mr Winstone said the inquiry looked at the number of licences that should be granted and there was general agreement that 50 was the right number. A proposed licence fee of £992 was reasonable because it enabled the Agency to recover the costs of managing the fishery. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943265

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Man's rape conviction quashed after six years in jail
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who has spent more than six years in prison after being convicted of raping and assaulting a teenage girl will have his convictions overturned by three top judges this week. Kenneth Samuels, 50, of Maes Glyndwr, Treuddyn, was sentenced to 10 years in jail at Mold Crown Court in January 2001 after a jury found him guilty of the rape and indecent assault of the girl. But Mr Samuels always protested his innocence and on Friday – after the case had been referred to the Criminal Appeal Court by the Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC), the body set up to investigate possible miscarriages of justice – three judges said the convictions were "unsafe". Representing Mr Samuels, Peter Wilcock told the court new evidence had come to light since the convictions, which, if it had been available at the time of the trial, could have influenced the way in which the jury viewed the case. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943819

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Neighbour rescues woman in flat blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN helped rescue one of his neighbours who was choking on thick smoke after a fire broke out in her flat. Residents at a block of flats at Fairy Road, Wrexham, escaped on Friday night after hearing a smoke alarm, and have praised the swift response of fire crews. David Davies, 33, helped a 44-year-old woman out of the building after seeing her struggling in the smoke in one of the flats upstairs. His girlfriend Jane Prince, 36, helped get the children including her daughter, Cathy, four, and other residents out of the building. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943405

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Probe after arsonists strike at city flat
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE are on the hunt for arsonists who attacked a flat in Chester. The fire, which caused extensive damage to 43 Medlar Close, Lache, was put out by firefighters at 3.30 on Sunday morning. Flat owner Kathy May, who at the time was away in Cumbria with her six-year-old son, was being comforted by family yesterday. Her sister, Stephanie Whyborn, told the Leader: "I feel so sorry for her. "Everything has gone, her clothes, her son\'s clothes, her bed was burnt – everything." The fire, on the second floor, caused extensive smoke damage to four other flats within the building. Two pumps from Chester Fire Station attended the incident. Two women from the flat upstairs, which became smokelogged, had to be rescued by firefighters and were lifted down a ladder. They were taken to the Countess of Chester Hospital but were allowed home after four hours. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943853

properties.name: 11/06/07 - Son's anger at dad's wait for ambulance
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ELDERLY man was forced to wait 40 minutes in agonising pain because there were no ambulances in Wrexham to get to him sooner, his son has claimed. Francis Parry, 73, of Falcon Road in Wrexham, fell in the kitchen breaking his thigh bone. He spent 12 hours on the kitchen floor before dragging himself to the phone. When his son Mark, 36, arrived the next day he saw his father needed emergency help. He rang the ambulance at 1.22pm and 20 minutes later there was no sign of it arriving. The ambulance arrived 40 minutes later and an angry Mark asked why there had been such a long wait and claims to have been told that there were no ambulances in Wrexham and that the ambulance had come from Corwen. Mr Parry\'s son said: "I find it disgusting that there weren\'t any ambulances in Wrexham county. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943027

properties.name: 11/07/07 - Cyclist seriously injured in park
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MAN, believed to be in his late 30s, has been left "seriously hurt" after a cycle accident in a Wrexham park. Wrexham Council says it is still gathering facts about the incident that happened in a wooded area of Acton Park. Phil Walton, strategic director said: "We are very concerned to hear about this incident in one of our parks and our thoughts at this time are with his family. "We are currently in the process of establishing the facts." A local councillor said there have been problems in the area where the accident happened with children digging holes in the ground to build ramps for their bikes. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3020695

properties.name: 11/07/07 - PICTURE SPECIAL: Thousands gather to take part in Jubilee
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHOUSANDS of worshippers lined the streets of Buckley for a special religious celebration. People of all ages and denominations came together to proclaim their faith in the 151th Buckley Jubilee festival. Yesterday\'s Jubilee attracted one of the biggest crowds in years, with everyone from school children to pensioners joining in the procession.
