All the town\'s churches took part in the celebrations, as did schools and several community groups. Crowds congregated at The Common for a short religious service, then gathered on the streets to watch the parade of Sunday School floats. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3020376

properties.name: 11/07/07 - TB tests at school
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A TUBERCULOSIS scare at a local school has resulted in screening tests being offered to staff and children. Over 250 pupils and staff at Holywell High School who have been in close contact with a staff member diagnosed with TB, were tested yesterday. However, the National Public Health Service of Wales (NPHS) has stressed the likelihood of TB spreading to the children is \'very low\'. The results of the screening are likely to be known in a few weeks. The member of staff, who has been off work since May 24, was admitted to Glan Clwyd Hospital but has now been discharged and is recovering well. Testing of the adult\'s close household contacts has shown there has been no spread of the infection. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3020634

properties.name: 11/07/07 - Village motorway row at boiling point
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineANGRY protesters against the proposed \'North Wales Motorway\' lashed out at Welsh Assembly officials at a sensational public meeting. Residents and councillors are calling for an immediate halt to the public inquiry into the so-called "North Wales Motorway" through Deeside, claiming the Assembly is refusing to acknowledge a possible alternative route over the Flintshire Bridge. A panel of officials and engineers, attending a pre-meeting inquiry at the A55 Holiday Inn said they had no knowledge of any alternative proposals. The inspector, Neil Taylor, who chaired the meeting, asked Assembly QC Milwyn Jarman if objectors had "suggested any alternatives to the scheme". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3020941

properties.name: 12 treated after lorry chemical spill
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAT LEAST a dozen people had to be decontaminated after a chemical leak from a lorry. A heavy goods vehicle containing ethylene dibromide, a toxic and potentially fatal chemical, had been towed to Autolift Recovery Ltd, on Chester Road, Backford, yesterday (August 14). It had been taken to the garage after an accident on the M53, on Monday, when a 42-year-old Manchester man died at the wheel of his HGV. The man was found dead in the cab of the lorry by highways patrol officers on the hard shoulder of the northbound carriageway of the M53 at junction nine, at about 3.30pm. Countess of Chester Hospital director of communications and marketing Stephen Winterson said: "Twelve patients were taken to the Countess of Chester Hospital and all were observed for a few hours and were released after routine blood samples were taken. "All 12 patients will be back in 48 hours though for an X-ray as this type of chemical, Ethylene Eibromide, can produce late onset problems." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3112570

properties.name: 12/06/07 - BBC presenter joins Blue Planet campaign
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA BBC presenter has joined forces with an aquarium to raise awareness of the world\'s oceans. Fresh from presenting BBC 2 programme Coast, ocean enthusiast Miranda Krestovnikoff attended an Ocean Awareness gala dinner at the Blue Planet Aquarium to highlight the importance of looking after the world\'s seas and supporting the Marine Reserves Now campaign. The campaign, designed to encourage the Government to create a network of Marine Reserves around the UK coast where marine life is protected from exploitation was discussed as part of Ocean awareness weekend which ran between June 9 and 10. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2943980

properties.name: 12/06/07 - Car clamper attacked with clamp
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ANGRY driver struck a vehicle clamper after learning his car had been targeted in Chester. The man returned to Crook Street, Newtown, to find his car had been clamped. Two men were working as vehicle clampers on the street and the offender struck one of them with part of a clamp, leaving him with a broken left arm. Cheshire Constabulary spokesman Glyn Hellam said: "The disgruntled vehicle owner is described as mixed race, 5ft 7in tall and in his late 20s. "He was wearing a black T-shirt with a striped motif on the front. "He was accompanied by another man who is described as white, tall and slim with short dark hair who had no part in the incident on Monday, June 4. "They both made off in a white van." Police are appealing for anyone with information to contact DC Mike Beamish at Chester Specialist Investigation Unit on 0845 458 0000 or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2946010

properties.name: 12/06/07 - TB tests at school in disease scare
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  A TUBERCULOSIS scare at a local school has resulted in screening tests being offered to staff and children. More than 200 pupils and staff members at Holywell High School who have been in close contact with a certain member of staff diagnosed with TB, have been offered the tests. A meeting will be held after school on Thursday, when concerned parents can ask questions to a panel of health experts. However, the National Public Health Service of Wales (NPHS) has stressed the likelihood of TB spreading to the children is "very low". The member of staff, who has been off work since May 24, was admitted to Glan Clwyd Hospital but has now been discharged and is recovering well. Testing of the adult\'s close household contacts has shown there has been no spread of the infection to them. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2945694

properties.name: 12/06/07 - Villagers flock to save surgery
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline HUNDREDS of residents are backing a campaign to keep a Bagillt surgery open. Doctors J. C. Kapoor and locum T. R. Lakshmish, whose main surgery is Allt Goch Medical Centre in Flint, have applied to the Flintshire Local Health Board (FLHB) to close Wern Surgery in Bagillt. A petition against the closure organised by Shirley Edwards has now attracted 402 signatures and is due to be handed to Cllr Kevin Jones later this week. Wern Surgery currently operates three days a week and has 405 patients on its books. In the application presented to the FLHB, Dr Kapoor set out several reasons for closing the surgery. He said for the period of August to December, 2006 compared to the same period in 2005, there was a drop of 111 in the number of patients attending sessions. There is also the problem of lone working with the receptionist having to open the surgery by herself to book patients in for the doctor and staying to clear things away and lock up after the doctor had left. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2945160

properties.name: 12/07/07 - Gentle giant Richard lifts title in memory of his uncle
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA GENTLE giant, who stormed to victory in a national strongman competition, dedicated his victory to his uncle\'s memory. Richard Smith, 18, who won the novice section of London\'s Strongest Man contest, was very close to his late uncle Laurence Horn, who died in a car crash in Northop Hall two years ago, aged 23. Last August, Richard, of King\'s Avenue, Flint, brought tears to the eyes of mum Lorraine, Laurence\'s sister, and the rest of the family with an outstanding performance in the professional section of the UK Strongman North contest in Northwich, where he finished ninth. At the weekend Richard, who is 6ft 5ins tall and weighs in at a whopping 25 stone, won every single category winning himself a trophy and £350. His proud mum said: "The competition was one of the qualifiers for Britain\'s Strongest Man competition and he got maximum points out of 33 contestants from all over the country. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3026648

properties.name: 12/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Councillor calls for city's subways to be closed
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineChester\'s graffiti-ridden subways should be closed for good. The unpopular city centre passageways, which many pedestrians avoid for fear of being attacked, should be shut and replaced by puffin and toucan crossings. That is the view of Cllr Peter Byrne, whose patch includes the city centre, who is pressing for action as soon as possible in a motion to today\'s meeting of Cheshire County Council. "The time has arrived to find new solutions for the subway problems," said Cllr Byrne. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3025939

properties.name: 12/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Memorials to be flattened over health and safety fears
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline GRAVESTONES classed as a hazard are to be laid flat amid fears someone could be seriously injured or even killed. Concern has been expressed by the parochial church council over the safety of a number of memorials at St Matthew\'s Parish Church, Buckley. Some date back to 1822, when the first church was built on the site, and have now become unstable and could pose a danger to visitors. The issue has become a thorny one in recent times as there have been a number of incidents across Wales where unsafe gravestones have fallen over and injured mourners paying their respects. However, some mourners have claimed laying gravestones flat is an "act of vandalism". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3025634

properties.name: 12/07/07 - Overcrowded houses are splitting up communities
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOMMUNITIES in Wrexham are being split up because of overcrowded properties full of hot bedding students and economic migrant workers, it was claimed this week. One councillor claimed that the problem is getting so bad in some parts of the town entire families are moving out of the area. Wrexham Council must tackle the problem of overcrowded properties before tensions among residents grow further, he warned. Cllr Alun Jenkins said some families in his ward had already decided to move out because of the problems created by residents of multiple occupancy homes. Problems including parking, noise and household waste issues were splitting communities, he warned. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3025408

properties.name: 12/07/07 - Pupils hope they won't slip up on Grease
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineYOUNGSTERS in Chester take to the stage for a second time tonight. Pupils of Blacon High School have been going through lengthy rehearsals for their production of the musical Grease, made famous on the big screen by John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John, and put on their first performance last night for an audience of fellow pupils, teachers and governors, family and friends. Pupils have been giving up their lunchtimes, as well as early mornings and after school time to practice for the show. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3026979

properties.name: 13/06/07 - 'Business as usual' after TB alert
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePARENTS at Holywell High School are being reassured it is business as usual after a TB scare. Screening tests are being offered to 210 staff and children who have been in close contact with a member of staff at the school who has been diagnosed with TB. However, the National Public Health Service say the risk of the disease spreading is very low and there have been no reported cases of any children coming down with TB. And Flintshire Council\'s education department has confirmed that the school is operating as normal. A spokesman said: "Acting on the advice of the National Public Health Service for Wales, letters and information sheets are being sent to the parents of children who will need to be screened. "The school and the LEA will continue to liaise closely with the National Public Health Service for Wales team dealing with this matter. "The school will continue to operate normally." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2946498

properties.name: 13/06/07 - Churchyard yobs smash up ancient tomb
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineVANDALS seriously damaged a 19th century grave in a churchyard wrecking spree in a bid to find a body, a canon fears. Yobs targeted St Giles Parish Church in Wrexham in an attack which has left rector canon Geoffrey Marshall and volunteers \'disgusted\' as they count the cost of repairs. The vandalism to the grave, which dates back to 1803, is the latest in a series of incidents of anti-social behaviour in the area surrounding the church. Volunteer John Griffiths said: "You can\'t get inside their mind can you? It is really terrible. I am absolutely disgusted, especially when you think of all the men working here every day to keep the place tidy." The Leader was shown a number of areas in the church grounds which have been blighted with graffiti, litter and criminal damage. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2948754

properties.name: 13/06/07 - Flintshire beauty spot touted on the internet as a sex site
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTRANGERS meeting for sex in a beauty spot are making life a nightmare for local families. Internet chatrooms are directing hoards of people looking for casual sex with strangers to Penymynydd woods. For years, residents and councillors have been concerned that the quiet woodland off the A5104 is being used as a meeting place for men searching for sex in public. But the numbers parking up in the lay-bys around the woods are growing due to the use of online \'cottaging\', \'dogging\' and \'cruising\' forums recommending the Flintshire site to hundreds of people across the UK and even abroad. As a result, dog walkers, residents and even children have witnessed men and couples performing sex acts in the woods, which are part of the Gladstone Estate and the bordering St John the Baptist Primary School. Police say they are aware of the activities and are constantly patrolling the area. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2948392

properties.name: 13/07/07 - Chris makes a splash with record-breaking swim
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineThe annual race night enjoyed near perfect conditions, enabling Chris Malpass to break a course record for the Dee Mile Championship, which was started in 1922 and has experienced a comeback in recent years. This year\'s event proved highly successful, with 76 entrants competing in three categories, watched by supporters lining the river bank. The Dee Mile championship is presented to the fastest swimmer, who must live within five miles of The Cross in the centre of Chester and must swim without a wetsuit. Chris, of the City of Chester Triathlon Club, smashed the previous championship record by 34 seconds, with a time of 20 minutes 1 second. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3029650

properties.name: 13/07/07 - Council promise tough new clampdown on yobs
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM council\'s leader has today outlined major plans to come down hard on people out to make the lives of residents a misery with anti-social behaviour. Aled Roberts has revealed councillors throughout Wrexham are contacted about unruly drunken behaviour and vandalism more than anything else and added the town had seen an increase in the number of incidents over recent weeks. He said: "This year anti-social behaviour is one of the council\'s priorities. The crime figures in Wrexham are significantly down. There are still some areas, such as common assault, where it is still more difficult to get reductions we would hope for. "The thing councillors get contacted most about is rowdy nuisance and neighbourhood incidences, so we feel we need to get more proactiove to tackle this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3028746

properties.name: 13/07/07 - Get fit for summer
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA GYM is encouraging people to get trim in time for summer – if and when it eventually arrives! Leaders of Chester and District Sports and Recreation Trust (CADSART), based at the Northgate Arena, are backing the national Look Good Feel Great campaign aimed at encouraging people to take part in physical activity. CADSART health and fitness officer Steve Edwards hopes newcomers will take the opportunity to improve their confidence and fitness ahead of the bikini season. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3029108

properties.name: 13/07/07 - How a Chirk firm helped bring the latest Harry Potter film to life
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSET designers used thousands of wood panels from a firm in Chirk to create the Ministry of Magic, in the latest Harry Potter film. For the biggest set ever built in the series, 30,000 MDF tiles were transported for use in the latest film, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix. The sales team at Kronospan, the wood chip manufacturer in Chirk, were approached to supply huge quantities to create the sets for the filming of the fifth book in the series. The MDF boards were used to create the infamous Ministry of Magic, the largest set ever built for the Harry Potter films. At more than 200 feet long, 120 feet wide and 30 feet high, it took more than 30,000 MDF tiles to cover it, all of which had to be individually placed. The Ministry of Magic is set in downtown London and has a network of basements and cellars underground. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3028505

properties.name: 13/07/07 - My girl deserved so much more than the name 'prostitute'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MOTHER has spoken of her battle to change the laws and rescue her daughter\'s reputation, four years after she was brutally killed after falling into a life of prostitution. Dianne Parry is travelling the country and tackling Government ministers in a bid to keep the memory of her late daughter alive. The body of her 19-year-old daughter, Hanane, a sex worker and former pupil of St David\'s High School, Saltney, had been discovered in a Liverpool alleyway, dismembered and stuffed into bin bags. She had turned to prostitution to fund her £100-a-day heroin habit. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3029193

properties.name: 13/07/07 - Roodee Open Course closed on Friday
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePUNTERS bound for Chester races will have \'minimal disruption\' this weekend despite challenging Roodee conditions, say course managers. All races today and tomorrow are set to proceed as normal, but the rain-drenched Open Course will be closed tonight. People who already have Open Course tickets for tonight will have them upgraded to the Dee Stand. Racecourse communications manager Melissa Hatton said: "In order to preserve the Open Course in as good a condition as possible for Saturday and the remainder of the season, the Racecourse has made a decision to stop the sale of all Open Course tickets to racegoers on Friday, July 13, with immediate effect." The Open Course is due to be re-open again for tomorrow\'s races. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3027110

properties.name: 13/07/07 - Royal Mail hit by strike two
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORKERS at Mold\'s postal sorting offices joined the picket lines today as part of a second nationwide strike. The Communication Workers Union and Royal Mail are locked in a bitter dispute over pay and jobs, and at 7pm yesterday up to 130,000 workers walked out in the second 24-hour strike in less than a month. Workers from Mold\'s sorting office formed picket lines to vent their frustration. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3028762

properties.name: 14/05/07 - Ambushed on walk home from pub
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN was left injured after being ambushed by four men as he walked home from a night at the pub. The victim, who has not been named by police, was kicked and punched to the legs and stomach after being jumped on by the attackers, all wearing dark clothing. The 37-year-old from Summerhill was treated at the Wrexham Maelor Hospital for severe bruising hours after the vicious street attack. Police have been carrying out door to door enquiries close to where the assault took place on Hill Street, Summerhill. The unsuspecting victim had been walking along the street after leaving the King William pub when the attack took place. For the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2874956

properties.name: 14/05/07 - Illegal gipsy camp to be moved
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTRAVELLERS camped out in a field on the outskirts of Chester will be forced to move on by the end of the week at the latest. The group, in about 15 caravans, took up residence in the field near the Wrexham Road park and ride facility over the bank holiday weekend, They are still on the site, despite a warning for them to move on being issued by Chester City Council, which owns the land. City council spokeswoman Kathryn McGiveron said: "They are illegally camped there. We served a notice to Chester County Court on Thursday for the travellers to move on. "There will now be a hearing at 10am on Wednesday, when we hope the judge will grant the order giving them 24 hours to vacate. So they should be off the land by Friday." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2875188

properties.name: 14/05/07 - Police blitz Crystal Meth drug labs
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE mounted a day-long operation in Mold in a crackdown on a drug that has become one of the world\'s most addictive stimulants. Officers in white chemical suits and gas masks executed two warrants to search premises in Chester Street and an address in Glan Alun under the Misuse of Drugs Act. They were searching for highly-addictive class A drug Methamphetamine, better known as \'Crystal meth\', and the paraphernalia used in its production. Due to the dangers associated with the drug, the specially-trained team cordoned off Chester Street to keep residents and pedestrians at bay while they entered the first premises and also cordoned off the junction of Brook Street and Bryn Coch Lane while officers searched the Glan Alun address. For the full story see: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2875070

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Dad died days after roof fall
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has died days after falling from a skylight while working as a roofing contractor. Paul Alker, of Brynteg, known as Little Will, was working as a contractor at the Comet store in Wrexham on Thursday when he fell and was admitted to hospital with a broken collar bone. He was allowed home for the weekend to see his family but was re-admitted for surgery on Monday. The operation to put pins in his collar bone was successful and he was laughing and joking in the ward the same evening. But the following morning his partner received a call saying that Mr Alker had collapsed and died. The family are waiting for post mortem results to reveal the cause of death. Paul, who was born in Liverpool, lived in Brynteg from the age of three. He attended Brynteg Primary School and then Groves High School. He started work as a construction worker as he loved to be outside. He was only three days in to his new job as a roofing contractor when the accident occurred. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2953835

properties.name: 14/06/07 - End of an era as city's Odeon cinema closes
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline CHESTER\'S last remaining city centre cinema will close for good tonight - June 14. A year-long campaign – led by city MP Christine Russell and backed by thousands of people from in and around Chester – to keep the much-loved Odeon up-and-running has failed. The management of Odeon UCL Cinemas Ltd has given up its tenancy of the Grade II listed "iconic" art deco building in Hunter Street, and the building\'s owners, South Yorkshire-based nightclub specialist The Brook Group, will now attempt to persuade the city council to favour its plans for the cinema complex which celebrated its 70th birthday last October. The 25 Odeon staff have promised The Brook Group they will vacate the building by June 30. An Odeon spokesman said: "We would like to thank all guests who have visited the cinema over the years. We would also like to thank the Odeon team members who have contributed so much to the running of the cinema." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954356

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Massive hunt for boys, 7, after school dare
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A PLAYGROUND dare spiralled into a huge three-hour search across Deeside for two missing schoolboys. Thankfully, the boys were found safe and well and the mother of one of them has expressed her thanks to the police officers, dog handlers, the helicopter team and members of the public who searched frantically for the children. At around 1pm on Tuesday, Maria Cooke, of South Green, Sealand, was at work when she received the phone call every parent dreads. A teacher from Sealand Community Primary School informed her that her son Stephen Edwards, seven, had been missing for the last 20 minutes and was nowhere to be found on school property. The school had notified the police and two officers came to collect Maria from work. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954023

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Midnight dip man warned of river perils
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who went for a midnight dip in the River Dee "because he was cold" has been warned he could have put his life in danger. The man, thought to be in his mid to late 30s, was spotted by a concerned member of the public wading around the weir near the Old Dee Bridge in Handbridge He was wearing shorts and had left his other clothes at the Bandstand near the Groves. When Chester Fire Station crew arrived, the man was swimming near the bank of the Salmon Leap flats in Handbridge. Blue Watch firefighter Andy Doyle said: "I was on the rescue boat and the man was wading across the weir in the river, and then swimming near the bank of the Salmon Leap flats. "He seemed a bit confused and we said to him that he should come out but he said he didn\'t see there was any danger. "This isn\'t true. Even though it is the summer, there were several dangers lurking. "The current is unpredictable, and debris could come up, the temperature is pretty cold, and despite it being summer if anyone is in deep water for too long they could catch hypothermia." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2953817

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Mum's alarm at missing hand scrub in hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MOTHER who took her son to Accident and Emergency at Wrexham\'s Maelor Hospital has spoken of her alarm at seeing empty soap dispensers in the waiting room. The mother, who does not want to be identified, took her son to the hospital after he broke his arm. She said: "Apart from the lengthy wait, what concerned me and other patients was the lack of disinfectant hand scrub in the waiting area. There were bottles attached to the wall but these were empty. "Myself and others did ask at the reception desk and told them the bottles were empty but the receptionist told us all that she had told the nurses at least four times and they had not filled them up." The same day the lady visited a friend in the hospital who told her the patient opposite had been isolated as she had contracted MRSA. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2950193

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Village's annual scarecrow trail keeps drivers on their toes
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA scarecrow dressed as a policeman has had drivers hitting the brakes in one Cheshire village. A scarecrow dressed as a policeman has had drivers hitting the brakes in one Cheshire village. The masterpiece was created by Christopher Strong, of Warrington Road, Mickle Trafford, who made the scarecrow as part of a Scarecrow Trail in the area, which began on Monday. Traffic began to slow and put on their brakes along the 40mph stretch of road after mistaking the scarecrow for a policeman and so Mr Strong, 58, felt obliged to move the it into his driveway. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2952933

properties.name: 14/06/07 - Villagers defiant after yobs attack scarecrows
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 14/06/07 - £1.3m revamp underway to transform city's station road
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORK has begun on the £1.3 million scheme to transform the road and footways outside Chester Railway Station. A 150-year-old Birkenhead Railway company manhole cover was lifted to mark the event which will be stored until it is moved to a new location once the project is completed. During the six month scheme York stone will replace the existing flagstones outside the station and the roundabout is to be moved near the station\'s west pay and display car park. The station square is to be remodelled with the taxi rank moved from the east wing to the west, linked to City Rail Link buses. There will also be a drop off point and short stay car parking. Six new bus stops with shelters will be placed either side of City Road as well as in the square itself and parts of the road are to be reconstructed and resurfaced. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2954898

properties.name: 15.08.07 - Ambulance attacked as crew treated patient
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMINDLESS yobs have been told they are putting people\'s lives at risk after attacking an ambulance while a paramedic treated a patient. The senseless late-night attack took place in Connah\'s Quay on Saturday, putting the paramedic and the female casualty in danger, while the emergency response vehicle was forced off the road. Ambulance officers have condemned the anti-social behaviour from the group of youths in Connah\'s Quay and warned more incidents like this, resulting in the loss of equipment, could put patient\'s lives on the line. The ambulance was called to the car park at the back of Birch Court in Connah\'s Quay at 11.20pm after a call reporting a woman had fallen over. While the paramedic treated his patient in the rapid response vehicle (RRV), youths threw bricks and two video recorders at the emergency vehicle, causing damage to the tailgate and the roof. The RRV is now out of action while vital repair work is carried out in a bid to get it back on the road by the weekend. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3112056

properties.name: 15.08.07 - Campaigners give up fight to save site for medical use
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCAMPAIGNERS fighting to retain a disused hospital for medical purposes look to have lost their fight. A bitter dispute has been raging over plans to demolish the disused Dobshill Hospital near Buckley and to sell the land for housing. In February, and contrary to recommendations from Flintshire Council\'s planning officials, councillors on the authority\'s planning committee voted to reject the Welsh Assembly\'s plans. Joined by residents, they argued the land should be used for commercial, business or medical use rather than residential purposes, and said access to the site would be insufficient and the road system would not be able to cope with the increased traffic. The case was due to go before an independent inspector at a public inquiry next month but Flintshire Council has now withdrawn its opposition after the authority\'s legal team said it would likely lose on appeal and the council would have to pay up to £100,000 in costs. The decision was made at an emergency meeting on Tuesday. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3111459

properties.name: 15.08.07 - Quick-thinking family escape house blaze
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A FAMILY have been praised by a top fire officer for their actions after they made a dramatic escape from a fire in their home. Jamie Randall, 20, his father Thomas and mother Roslyn had a lucky escape after a fire started in an upstairs bedroom of the house in Bron-y-Waun, Chirk. On hearing a smoke alarm, Jamie and his father went upstairs and on seeing the fire, called for Roslyn to get out, who was in the next room. They put wet towels on the fire, closed the door and got out of the property as quickly as possible. Jamie said: "I was downstairs and my dad was playing with some new phones we had. "I heard the smoke alarm – at first I thought it was my dad\'s phone so I asked him what the noise was and he said \'it\'s not me\'. "So I went upstairs and saw the TV and curtains on fire and then I told my mum to get out. "My dad came up and then my mum and dad got two wet towels and tried to put the fire out. "But then we left it, shut the door, got out and called the fire brigade. "If I hadn\'t have heard the smoke alarm, I wouldn\'t have known there was a fire." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3111243

properties.name: 15/05/07 - Hands off our police
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA GROUP of councillors, including the incoming Mayor of Wrexham, has slammed cuts to police numbers in their wards. Cllr Joan Lowe has been joined by fellow county councillors Paul Pemberton, David Bithell and Mark Pritchard in condemning North Wales Police moves to reduce the number of beat managers (CBMs) serving the Penycae, Ruabon, Pant, Ponciau, Johnstown and Rhos area. So far, one CBM is definitely being moved out of the area, and community councils fear they will lose more in the near future. The group met at Rhos police station to voice their anger, and were joined by community councillors and residents from around the county borough, who say they are concerned at the reduction in front line policing. For the full story follow the link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2877594

properties.name: 15/05/07 - Hospital 'one of the best in UK'
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline

properties.name: 15/05/07 - Record last day at races
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA RECORD crowd turned out to the final day at Chester Racecourse\'s May Festival. More than 23,600 attended City Day at the Roodee on Friday as the three-day meeting came to a close. The impressive crowd repaired some of the damage done to attendance figures by rain earlier in the festival. Chief executive Richard Thomas said: "The crowd figure today is up four per cent on last year at a record 23,627, which is testament to the popularity of the May Festival as we haven\'t been nearly as lucky with the weather this year. "The total number of people over the three days is 63,116, which is one per cent less than 2006." To see the full story follow the link: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2875686

properties.name: 15/05/07 - Station good for village claims
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN AM has moved to address residents\' fears over proposals for a new station in a village. Rossett has been earmarked as the site for a possible new station and park-and-ride scheme in a survey of Wrexham\'s rail links. Residents, however, are worried that some aspects of the proposals could be damaging to the village. Their concerns included the increase in traffic caused by people using the park-and-ride, and the possibility of a large open car parking space leading to an increase in vandalism and anti-social behaviour. North Wales AM Eleanor Burnham, who lives in the village, has been campaigning for a rail link in Rossett for many years, and says she sees it as a way to open up the community to the outside world. For the full story click on the link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2876380

properties.name: 15/05/07 - Travellers buy school for £70,000
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A GROUP of travellers say they are confident they will get the green light for a permanent site and claim they have even bought a £70,000 school building for the camp. Gipsies living on the Bagillt Road site in Holywell have confirmed they have the deeds to the site and are in the process of transforming it into a permanent camp. Although a number of children from the camp are now attending local primary schools, the travellers say they have ordered a two-storey wooden building from Russia to offer an on-site classroom. The travellers, who moved onto the former coal yard from council land in Rhydymwyn, are currently seeking retrospective planning permission for the site and have hired a planning consultant. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2877667

properties.name: 15/06/07 - Man arrested over roofer's death
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter by gross negligence after a father of one died days after falling from a skylight at a Wrexham store. Paul Alker, 33, was working as a roofing contractor at the Comet store on Mount Street when he fell last Thursday. Mr Alker, of Holborn Crescent, Brynteg, was admitted to hospital with a broken collar bone, and discharged over the weekend. He underwent surgery on his injury on Monday and appeared to be well that evening, but the following morning his partner received a call to say he had collapsed and died. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2957417

properties.name: 16.08.07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Assembly: We will not abandon A494 plans
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePROTESTERS in Deeside are furious after a Welsh Assembly minister refused to abandon plans to turn the A494 into the \'North Wales Motorway\'. They were hoping the appointment of Deputy First Minister Ieuan Wyn Jones as Transport Minister would lead to a review of the proposed A494 expansion. However, the Assembly has told the Leader that Mr Wyn Jones will be pressing ahead with the plans, championed by his predecessor, Andrew Davies. More than 2,000 residents wrote to Mr Davies calling for the scheme, which would see the 50mph dual carriageway expanded into seven lanes of 70mph trafffic and slip roads extending to within feet of people\'s doorsteps, to be scrapped. A public inquiry, scheduled to begin next month, will go ahead, but the final decision will still be made by the Assembly and not by an independent inspector. Alyn and Deeside AM Carl Sargeant said Mr Wyn Jones had to take action against the scheme in the face of the enormous public opposition. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3116672

properties.name: 16.08.07 - You can't top the Reds' passion
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM football fans are among the most passionate in the land, a new survey claims. Almost two thirds, 59 per cent, confess to wearing nothing but their club colours even when doing the housework, according to research by Virgin Media. A spokesperson for the company said: "It seems Wrexham\'s football fans are already in a league of their own when it comes to showing their support." Responses by more than 5,100 football fans of clubs across the country revealed one in five would forgo getting their foot on the property ladder to fund their love affair with the beautiful game. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3112861

properties.name: 16/05/07 - Axe falls on city centre cinema
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline CHESTER city centre\'s only remaining cinema is to close next month with a potential loss of 25 jobs. A year-long campaign to keep the Odeon up-and-running would appears to have failed. The much-loved Grade II listed art deco building will show its final films on June 14, the company has confirmed. The announcement of the closure has increased fears that the cinema, which celebrated its 70th birthday last October and which hosted the regional premiere of James Bond blockbuster Casino Royale, will now be converted into a nightclub. For the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2882377

properties.name: 16/05/07 - Couple attacked in own home by burglars
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineThe man and woman were returning to their home in Overton when they were set upon by two men. The men attacked them and demanded money, before fleeing the property with cash and jewellery. Police say they were informed of the burglary at just after 11pm on Monday, and detectives are appealing for witnesses to help them track down the offenders. The couple suffered minor injuries in the incident. Anyone who may have seen or heard anything suspicious before to the incident is asked to contact North Wales Police on 0845 6071001 (Welsh language line), 0845 6071002 (English language line) or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555111. To see the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2879818

properties.name: 16/05/07 - Driver in hospital after A55 pile-up
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A DRIVER was rushed to hospital this morning after a pile up on the A55. The North Wales Fire and Rescue Service were alerted to a three-car crash on the eastbound carriageway of the A55 near the Broughton slip road shortly before 8am. Crews from Wrexham and Buckley were sent and the emergency tender from Wrexham was also deployed. One of the drivers was trapped in their vehicle and was released and rushed to Wrexham Maelor Hospital with injuries, the severity of which remains unknown. For the full story and pictures click on the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2880410

properties.name: 16/05/07 - Woman has baby in back of car after breakdown
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN was forced to give birth in the back of a car at the side of the road after an untimely breakdown during a dash to hospital. Lisa and Sean Roberts got as far as the Rossett turn-off on the A483, on route to the Wrexham Maelor Hospital, when the car shuddered to a halt. It soon became clear to the Connah\'s Quay couple that their second child was not prepared to wait to be born and a panicked Lisa went into labour shortly before 4am on Saturday. For the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2880108

properties.name: 16/05/07 - Woman killed in Blacon flats death plunge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MURDER probe has been launched after a woman died following a fall from a block of flats in Chester. A 46-year-old Blacon man was arrested yesterday for attempted murder, which was later changed to murder, after the 54-year-old woman died at the Countess of Chester Hospital. Police were called at about 10pm on Monday to the Glyn Garth flats complex on Nevin Road, Blacon, where the woman had fallen from an upper balcony of the fifth floor. A resident found her lying on the ground. At the flats yesterday, police tape sealed off the area where the woman had fallen and flowers lay on the ground bearing messages to \'Brony\' and \'Bron\'. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2881530

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Nazi symbol burnt into golf course
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline Yobs who scorched a 20ft by 20ft swatiska on one of the greens at Flint Golf Club have been branded as mindless vandals. Shocked club captain Bryan Strong said the damage was discovered by the greenkeeper early on Saturday morning and shockwaves spread as members came to see what had happened. Speaking from his motor sales business on Chester Street, Flint, Mr Strong said: "It\'s appalling. I can\'t imagine why anyone would do this. It\'s looks like the grass has been burned off with white spirit and they\'ve left the mark of a swastika. "I can only imagine it might be done out of envy, but we as a club welcome young members. We have 80 juniors who we subsidise. No other North Wales club does more than we do." Mr Strong, who confirmed that the police had been informed, said the club was still assessing the damage. He asked that anyone who may have seen anything suspicious should inform the police. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033295

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Polish ambassador on visit to town
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE Polish ambassador visited Wrexham to speak to students about why they came to the UK to study and work. Barbara Tuge-Erecin\'ska officially opened the gap personnel Training Suite in Charles Street, Wrexham. The suite has been launched as a partnership between the company and Yale College to provide basic skills training, IT and Learndirect courses to workers in the area. This is assisted with funding from the Welsh Assembly Government. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3032179

properties.name: 16/07/07 - Soccer team all kitted out for the Eisteddfod
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline The under-11 football team from Ysgol Glanrafon, Mold, will be sporting a brand new kit when they take part in the school knockout tournament at the National Eisteddfod, thanks to the support of Principality. The Welsh building society donated £240 towards a much-needed strip for the team, and Amanda Davies, from Principality in Mold, said: "We are delighted that we were able to support Ysgol Glanrafon through our branch sponsorship scheme. It\'s great to see the children rewarded for their hard work – and really enjoying having great fun playing football. We hope that their new kits will give them a boost of confidence for the competition this summer." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033079

properties.name: 17/05/07 - Anger over report into toxic dump
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA REPORT into a piece of land near Wrexham which was used as a dump for chemical waste has been blasted. Despite a decision that the area will not be classified as contaminated land, the report findings have failed to quell fears among councillors that the waste left at the former chemical tip near Rhos may eventually affect the health of residents living in the area. One councillor said the £40,000 survey to look into the problem was "not worth the paper it was written on". For the full story follow the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2884594

properties.name: 17/05/07 - Lorry ploughs into country cottage
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FAMILY home was devastated after a 44-ton articulated lorry crashed left the road and crashed into it before shedding its load of logs. The accident happened at Maybury Avenue, just outside Glyn Ceiriog, yesterday, when the lorry crashed through the front hedge and into the utility room of Ty Gwyn cottage, flattening the boiler and disabling the electricity and water systems, before tipping over and sending its load of 100 logs onto the family caravan and two sheds. At 9.45am, the owner of the house Martin Nee was at work when he received a phone call from his neighbour telling him there had been an incident and he should come home. "When I saw my house I was flabbergasted, shocked and devastated. Imagine a quaint country cottage with a lovely garden with a 44-ton artic on its side in the garden. My wife is devastated and in tears. I saw the driver with someone but I didn\'t want to speak to him," said Martin, 40. For pictures and the full story click on the link below: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2884533

properties.name: 17/05/07 - Parents plea for chance to save school
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline PARENTS and governors lobbied councillors this morning when they turned up at a meeting which could help decide the fate of their school. Boughton St Paul\'s Infants\' and Nursery School, on the edge of the city centre, may close by August, 2008. A decision edged closer after a School Planning Select Panel met at the end of April and voted to approve a recommendation to close the facility, and today the full council is meeting at County Hall to discuss the recommendation. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2886069

properties.name: 17/05/07 - Tribute to flat death woman
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHILDREN of a woman who was killed after falling from the fifth floor of a block of Chester flats have released a tribute to her. Bronwen Jackson, 54, who lived at Glyn Garth flats complex on Nevin Road, Blacon, was killed on Monday (May 14) night after falling from an upper balcony. She sustained serious injuries and died at the Countess of Chester Hospital. In a statement released through Cheshire Constabulary her son, Paul Williams, and daughter, Kelly Wilson, said: "We\'ve lost a caring mother who adored her children and grandchildren. To read the full story follow the link below: http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2886391

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Council criticised over care of vulnerable youngsters
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA REPORT into children\'s social services in Wrexham has criticised the county\'s arrangements for protecting vulnerable children. In a report to be presented to the children and young people\'s scrutiny committee tomorrow, councillors will be told an inspection carried out by the Care & Social Services Inspectorate Wales found "significant gaps" in the service offered, particularly in the protection of children identified as at risk. Although the inspectors found many examples of good practice in children\'s social services, they pointed to child protection as an area of concern, and highlighted the arrangements surrounding case conferences as being in need of changes. The inspectors\' report says that although Wrexham has comparatively few children on the child protection register, the numbers had increased, with a particularly sharp rise at the end of last year. It says: "When a child is on the register for child protection, plans are not sufficiently specific or outcome-focused, and do not generally indicate what changes need to occur, who is responsible for ensuring change, within what timescale, and what contingency plans are in place. Strengths and weaknesses in the family are not routinely noted, and there is no risk analysis. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3033479

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Golf club's £80,000 repair bill over nazi symbol
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A GIANT Nazi symbol scorched into a golf green could land the club with a total repair bill of £80,000. Flint Golf Club is concerned the massive bill to repair the vandalism to four of their greens could ruin the club. On Sunday morning, greenkeeper Steven Roberts discovered a 20ft by 20ft swastika scorched into the course\'s first green, with what is believed to be petrol or diesel. The green was recently ranked the best in Wales by the Welsh Golfing Union and the course has won plaudits across the UK. Three other greens have also been targeted in the attack. Club captain Bryan Strong says each green could cost about £20,000 to repair. He said: "We are going to try and wash it out using chemicals and then re-seed it, which will take ages. "Our big concern is it\'s gone down into the roots and if that\'s the case we have a major problem. "It\'s £20,000 just for one green and I don\'t know where we are going to find that money, we\'re just a small club." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3035388

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Manhunt after Chester woman is doused in petrol
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE are hunting for a man who threw two litres of petrol over his former partner in Chester last night. It\'s claimed the woman, of Brentwood Road, Blacon, had petrol poured over her head and in her eyes, by her former partner, a 22-year-old man. Chester Fire Station Blue Watch Firefighter Jim Payne said on arrival at 7.15pm, the female was in a highly distressed state, standing in her kitchen. He said: "The 25-year-old woman had petrol covering her body. This could have been fatal if any ignition source had gone near her. It was a lucky escape for her." Five firefighters went into the kitchen and used tap water to douse the petrol off her skin. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3036189

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Rapist's horrific attack on widow, 74
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA \'monster\' who attacked and raped a pensioner in her own home has today been locked up indefinitely. Speaking after defendant Keith Sharpe, 34, was sentenced for the offences against a 74-year-old Wrexham woman, DI Jeremy Vaughan said: "This was a despicable and cowardly attack on a 74-year-old lady at her home address. "The resilience and true grit shown by this lady throughout the investigation has played no small part in the guilty plea and the subsequent sentence that Sharpe has now received. "The 74-year-old lady described how this incident ruined her life and she will continue to receive the support of the police Family Liaison Officer in order to try to begin to re-build her life and the long healing process ahead." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3035247

properties.name: 17/07/07 - Spruce yourselves up in time for Eisteddfod plea by MP
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineHOUSEHOLDERS in Flintshire are being asked to ensure their homes look pristine in time for next month\'s National Eisteddfod. The festival, which runs from August 4-11, on the Pentrehobyn Estate, Mold, is likely to attract more than 100,000 visitors and give the county\'s tourism industry a massive boost. And Alyn and Deeside MP Mark Tami wants all residents, and businesses, to ensure their homes and properties are blooming when it starts. Mr Tami also wants the county\'s streets to be clean and litter-free to create a good impression on those who visit Flintshire during the week. He said every effort should be made to showcase the county during the cultural celebrations. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3034798

properties.name: 17/08/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Protest grows over controversial business park
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  CONTROVERSIAL plans to build a business park and truck stop in north Flintshire could create up to 500 new jobs in the region. But residents living near the proposed development are furious and say if approved it will destroy the countryside. JD Owen Transport Services has applied for planning permission to build a secure truck parking facility and enterprise park on fields near Crossways Road, Caerwys. The company says universities, blue-chip hi-tech firms and a big-name national organisation are interested in occupying offices in the proposed development. JD Owen spokesman Roger Griffiths said if the proposed development one mile north of Caerwys is approved, up to 500 jobs will be created. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3120308

properties.name: 18/06/07 - Family devastated at sentence for attacker who left man paralysed
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE sisters of a man paralysed in a horrific knife attack at the hands of his partner\'s former husband say it is he who has been given a life sentence after his attacker was jailed. But victim Stephen Parry, who is now confined to a wheelchair, says his attacker, Anthony Charles Stephen, who was locked up indefinitely on Friday, has taken enough out his life and is not going to take any more. It later became clear that his attacker could be released in six years. In an interview with the Leader, they said that whatever sentence the knifeman received, it would never be enough for what he has done. The 54-year-old attacker from Rayon Road, Greenfield, near Holywell, admitted attempted murder on Friday and was given an indeterminate sentence at Mold Crown Court. Mr Parry, 45, is still undergoing treatment at the spinal injuries unit at Southport General Hospital, where partner Karen, the defendant\'s former wife, is constantly at his side. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961697

properties.name: 18/06/07 - Jobs axed at Wrexham firm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORKERS at a pharmaceuticals factory have been rocked after being told 92 of them are to lose their jobs. Wockhardt UK, based on Wrexham Industrial Estate, plans to cut staff in two phases, with 42 set to go in August, and the remainder in March next year. The plant employs 395 people, making tablets, ointments and sterile products for international customers. According to bosses, the cuts have been forced on them by changes to the industry picture and competition from rivals who have switched production to countries where labour is cheaper. Wockhardt managing director Sirjiwan Singh told the Evening Leader he was disappointed at having to make the decision. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961266

properties.name: 18/06/07 - Wrexham couple celebrate lottery win
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA YOUNG couple who are getting married next year now plan to do it in style after scooping a lottery windfall. Becky Williams and Chris Robertson, who both work at Airbus in Broughton and live in Caego, Wrexham, matched five numbers plus the bonus ball in the Lotto draw on Saturday, June 9, and won £164,028. Planner Becky, who picks the same numbers each week based on a combination of birthdays, recognised the digits when she checked the numbers on Sunday morning. "I was on the phone to my sister last week, talking about the cost of the wedding," said the 25-year-old. "I said to her \'Never mind, I\'m going to win the lottery on Saturday!\' Now it has actually happened I can\'t believe it." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961210

properties.name: 18/07/07 - Animal welfare award for city zoo
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTV VET Steve Leonard took time out to present a prestigious animal welfare award to Chester Zoo. The presenter of numerous shows, including Vets in Practice, Ultimate Killers and Orangutan Diaries, yesterday presented a team from the zoo and Durham University with the coveted Universities Federation for Animal Welfare Wild Animal Welfare Award, for a study which helped to reduce stress levels of the zoo\'s mandrills. The study discovered that planting a barrier of shrubs between the mandrills\' enclosure and the visitors\' viewing area improved the mandrills\' behaviour. Zoo research officer Dr Sonya Hill, who specialises in primate behaviour and welfare, was helped by two students, Riccardo Pansini and Jessica Hargreaves, from Durham University, where they were supervised by Dr Jan de Ruiter. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3039115

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: 'Use English first' call at rail stations
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM MP Ian Lucas has called for announcements at train stations to be made in English first. Mr Lucas is among seven Labour MPs to sign House of Commons motion, calling on a review of the current policy. The group want announcements in Welsh towns and cities with low numbers of Welsh speakers to be made in English first, claiming the current practice of using Welsh first causes confusion. The motion says the group "wholly support" the policy of bilingual announcements, but believe that "it would be far more sensible and far more convenient for passengers, whether regular commuters or local visitors, if announcements at each station were made first in the language used by the majority of the local population". Mr Lucas, who travels frequently by train and is not a Welsh speaker, said English should be used first in Wrexham and pointed out that the numbers of people staying in the area from abroad, who may speak English but not Welsh, was also a factor. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038211

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Calls for booze to be banned from streets
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM could become only the second place in the UK to enforce a county-wide ban on boozing in public places. It would also become the first authority in Wales to make the move if calls from an opposition leader on the council are carried out. Cllr Neil Rogers said residents in the town and the surrounding villages were "sick and tired" of having to put up with drunken yobs consuming vast amounts of alcohol on the streets and in parks. The councillor told yesterday\'s executive board meeting, during a debate on a new anti-social behaviour strategy, that Wrexham should be the first authority in Wales, and only the second in Britain, to introduce a total ban on boozing in all public places. Cllr Rogers said: "Every Friday and Saturday night, in every community in Wrexham borough, there is alcohol being consumed by young children. It is a concern which keeps coming up at every community council meeting and every residents\' meeting. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038495

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: I'll have to leave Wales for vital cancer treatment
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A MUM-of-two, struck down by cancer, has been denied vital treatment – because she lives in Wales. Samantha Cousins, 34, of Victoria Avenue, Johnstown, has been recommended for a bone marrow transplant as part of her two-year battle with Hodgkin\'s disease. She has been treated at Manchester\'s specialist Christie\'s Hospital, where consultant Dr Adrian Bloor recommended she be given the treatment. But because she lives in Wales, funding for Samantha\'s treatment has to come from Health Commission Wales, which blocked it, leaving her feeling she has been a victim of a "postcode lottery". Now, she says she may be driven to move from Wales to find somewhere where her transplant will be funded. She said: "I have been having chemotherapy for two years. The doctors said they would not be putting me forward for me to have the transplant if I did not need it, and if it would not help. "My treatment is working, and I need this as the next stage, but in the end it all comes down to the money." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3038216

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Parents in playground sewage fury
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  PARENTS have banned their children from using a playground, claiming it is swimming in sewage and has made the youngsters ill. The council-run playing fields were used by about 30 children from Deva Avenue, Bryn y Coed and the bottom of Bryn Mawr Road on Holywell\'s Strand estate. Now the playground is empty as parents claim their children have suffered stomach pains, sickness and diarrhoea after playing there. Residents say a basketball court in the park is drowned in a murky mess, smelling of sewage, along with dangerous debris, including planks of wood, a sharp-edged broken plastic container and an old car radio. Deva Avenue resident, Veronica Jones, who looks after her three-year-old nephew Thomas Lee, said: "A lot of kids on this avenue all go and play there. It\'s so close we feel safe letting them play there because we can look over the hedge and keep an eye out. "I let Thomas go and he came back covered in sewage, so I don\'t let him go anymore. All the kids are complaining of stomach aches and sickness and diarrhoea, one girl went to hospital a couple of weeks ago." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3040104

properties.name: 18/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY: Plans to scrap Glass Slug are on target
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineNEGOTIATIONS to kill off Chester\'s Glass Slug council offices are on track, say leading councillors. Conservative Town Hall rulers, who swept to power in May on a promise of doing away with proposed new city council offices, say discussions with the proposed developer ING are proceeding according to plan. Deputy council leader, Cllr Stephen Mosley, said: "Negotiations have begun and everything is proceeding as expected. As you would expect, we are prevented from saying too much for legal reasons. "The Glass Slug is a small part of a very complicated contract, but what has become apparent is that the rising costs of the scheme were threatening the whole plan to regenerate the city centre. "We have found and are continuing to find the developer ING very helpful, and we are confident of a deal that will be beneficial to the city, its taxpayers and its future prosperity. "It was never right to spend that sort of money on plush offices for Councillors." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3039175

properties.name: 19/06/07 - 11-year-old terrorised by gang for being disabled
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM mother says she and her disabled son are living in fear of children as young as seven who are making their lives a misery. Lisa Behrendt, 30, says she and 11-year-old Liam have been terrorised for months by a gang who mercilessly abuse and threaten them. Liam has scoliosis of the spine and speech problems, which have made him the target of bullies for months. And the teasing has reached such a level that it makes them feel like prisoners in their own home. Lisa said: "It is horrible. At times you just feel you can\'t go outside because of what they might say. "The things people say to my son are disgusting, things that I can\'t even bring myself to repeat. We keep ourselves to ourselves and don\'t want to cause any trouble for anyone, but it seems like they just won\'t leave us alone." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963053

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Driver steered with knees as he ate spaghetti
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA LORRY driver caught steering with his knees while he ate spaghetti from a pan, has been jailed for eight weeks after he admitted dangerous driving. Martin Veens was spotted driving his left-hand 40-tonne lorry erratically on the A55, near Northop. Prestatyn magistrates heard how North Wales Police\'s helicopter camera filmed him holding and eating from a saucepan as he steered with his knees. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963587

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Fury as web sites direct people to local hotspots
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOMMUNITY leaders have reacted furiously after various parts of Wrexham were named on the internet as hotspots for "dogging". A Leader investigation has found that websites are giving directions to sites in Johnstown, Chirk, Ruabon, Minera, Rhostyllen and Gwersyllt, guiding people looking for casual sex to areas, including rural beauty spots. According to the website Wrexham has the greatest number of "dogging" hotspots in North Wales. Among the sites singled out is the Wynnstay Woods area close to Ruabon, and local councillor Nick Colbourne said he was disgusted. He said: "This is terrible, particularly for people who live close to it. Imagine living near to that kind of thing going on. "Coincidentally, I was on the Leader website just the other day and noticed the poll on whether police should have more powers to cut back on this kind of thing. "I clicked \'yes\'. It is definitely something that should be stopped. Just to think about it happening in the area is horrible." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964046

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Mum and tot in car theft drama
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MOTHER has spoken of her anger after her car was stolen – just seconds after she had lifted her three-year-old son out of the vehicle. Paula Boyd had just taken Joshua out of his car seat when the thieves struck in broad daylight. The incident happened at 6pm on Thursday, on Station Road, Chester, opposite the Deva Mail Social Club. Paula said: "It was absolutely terrifying. I had just parked to buy some train tickets and post some letters and got Joshua out of the car, but before I could get his buggy from the boot I heard all this screaming and yelling. "Two men had taken the keys from the back seat and jumped into the car. They put the car in reverse, then drove forwards and began ramming the car in front so they could make their escape. "Another female motorist tried to block them with her car, but they got away." Paula, who lives in Upton, said she was still in shock a day later and is trying to come to terms with what happened. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963984

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Residents pull together as torrent of water hits village
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLOODING in Hawarden caused havoc for homeowners at the weekend. Environment Agency officers, the fire service and residents of Moore Close, Hawarden, turned out in force to stop the torrent of water damaging vehicles and property. Dave Evans, 37, an estate agent who lives at Moore Close, Hawarden, which saw the worst of the flooding, said: "In some places it was 14 inches deep. "The first thing we did was phone the fire brigade. Then the Environment Agency came out and brought loads of sand bags. They were fantastic." Only last month, a national weather review showed Hawarden had one of the highest rainfalls in the country with 26.4mm. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2962009

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Stop this race crime shame
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCall for help for migrant workers as Flintshire abuse figures soar MIGRANT workers need to given more help and support to settle in Flintshire, to reduce the alarming rise in racially-motivated hate crimes. That is the view of the North Wales Race Equality Network (NWREN) who say the shocking rise in the number of hate crimes in the county can only be combated if front-line services are improved to make migrant workers feel part of the community. As the Leader exclusively reported last month, there has been a 98 per cent rise in the number of violent, racist and abusive hate crimes in Flintshire in the last 12 months. And a new report by the NWREN says there is not enough support for non-Polish migrants trying to make a new life in Flintshire. It also says fear of being abused or attacked is a major concern for migrants who feel some of the county\'s town are \'unsafe\' which limits opportunities for social inclusion in community life. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964291

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Campaign fails to save school with 13 pupils
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline RESIDENTS have lost the struggle to save their village\'s only school and will watch helplessly when the doors finally close after 120 years. After months of petitioning and lobbying local representatives, the community of Rhydymwyn received the response it had dreaded – Ysgol y Ddol is to shut for good at the end of term. Flintshire Council claim they made the decision because pupil numbers had halved, to just 13, in five years. Headteacher Gwyn Lloyd-Jones said it means the "heart of the village is being ripped out". He said: "We have lost a pub in the past eight years, and the post office, and now the community is losing its school." Flintshire Council\'s executive member for education, Cllr Chris Bithell, said Ysgol y Ddol is closing because "numbers have declined to such an extent the school is not really viable any more." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3043525

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Museum revamp backed
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline COUNCILLORS have backed a £2.1 million revamp of Wrexham Museum, saying it will be a major boost to the town\'s cultural heritage. The renovation will make the facility more family friendly and popular, Wrexham Council\'s executive board meeting heard. Plans include a more inviting forecourt with better signs and more interactive and community-focused displays on the ground floor. A report said the estimate cost of the project is £2.1 million. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3040706

properties.name: 19/07/07 - River promenade dream becomes a reality after 10 years
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA 10-YEAR dream of riverside link between Chester and Flintshire is now a reality. The River Dee was the focus of lively celebrations as the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress of Chester, Cllr Jim Latham and his wife Hilary, officially opened the multi-million pound Riverside Promenade. The development, which has taken three years to complete, has been an aspiration of Chester City Council for a decade. Schoolchildren, residents and dignitaries came together to mark the official opening of e and enjoy parts of the River Dee which were previously inaccessible. Entertainment from a band and host of colourful characters added to the occasion and set out to bring the river\'s unique history to life. About 90 pupils from Victoria County Infant and St Thomas of Canterbury Junior schools joined Cllr Latham as the first people to officially walk the promenade. The journey ended at Chester\'s Old Port, where all of the children received certificates to mark their achievement. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3041117

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Swimmers' Dee-lightful fundraiser
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO Chester men have raised £500 through a sponsored swim in the River Dee. Tim Clifton, of Walter Street, Newtown, and Steve Walker, of Boughton Heath, braved the waters in a gruelling 5.5km swim from Eccleston to the Grosvenor Rowing Club, on The Groves. Tim, a teacher at Boughton Heath Primary School, Chester, said: "It took about an hour and 10 minutes to do, it was a bit quicker than we thought because the flow was with us. "We were probably one of the only people praying for rain because it meant it wasn\'t as hard." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3041113

properties.name: 19/07/07 - Woman hurt in gas blast
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN is being treated for burns after a gas explosion at her home. Fire crews and paradmedics were called to the scene of the explosion in Lixwm, near Holywell, at 6pm yesterday. It believed the blast was caused by the gas being left on or leaking in the day. When the woman returned, she inadvertently ingnited the fumes, causing an explosion of such force it shattered windows and blew a hole in the roof. Ambulance crews took the victim to Whiston Hospital, Merseyside, where she is now undergoing treatment for burns to the face and arms. A North Wales Fire and Rescue service spokesman said: "The gas had been left on all day and somehow exploded, leaving the lady with burns to her arms and face." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3043376

properties.name: 20/06/07 - 180 jobs go at Deeside firm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWorkers at a Deeside print works are distraught after being told they are to be made redundant. Graphoprint, on Deeside Industrial Estate went into administration "out of the blue" and the 180 workers were told yesterday they were to lose jobs. The magazine and catalogue printer went into administration on Friday and today the administrators, KPMG, have announced the company will be shedding about 180 jobs. The company was declared a "phoenix from the ashes" in April, 2005 when it survived a fire which severely damaged the building and equipment. Last year Graphoprint was bought by print veteran Chris Bramley, with the backing of asset financier CIT Print and invoice discounting company Eurotracker and went on to win a number of industry awards. The Leader has been flooded with calls from workers who say they were under the impression the company, with a turnover of £27m, was in good health and that these cuts had "come out the blue". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968020

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Breeder, 71, kept dogs in filthy, cramped conditions
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ELDERLY farmer could face jail after scores of dogs and puppies were found in cold, cramped and dirty conditions on his farm. Peter Hughes, of Ashford Farm, Caeau Gleision Lane, Halkyn, kept 64 dogs in what an RSPCA inspector described as some of the worst conditions he had ever seen. He had originally pleaded not guilty to 13 charges brought by the RSPCA of causing unnecessary suffering to dogs and two charges brought by Flintshire Council\'s Environmental Health department. But yesterday at Flint Magistrates\' Court, the 71-year-old pleaded guilty to six counts of causing unnecessary suffering to border collie-type dogs, one of keeping an establishment for the breeding of dogs for which no licence had been granted, and one of breaching the licence conditions of a pet shop licence. Chris Moss, prosecuting, told the court that between September, 2005 and March, 2006 Flintshire Council received complaints from members of the public who had bought puppies from Mr Hughes. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967233

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Club's ex-steward is cleared of stealing £14,742 from employer
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FORMER steward at Buckley Conservative Club has been cleared of stealing more than £14,000 from his employer. David William Griffiths, 47, was originally charged with stealing £2,110 from the club between June 25 and October 23, 2005, and £12,632 between October 20 and December 23 of the same year. Judge John Rogers QC, sitting at Mold Crown Court, directed the jury to find him not guilty of the first charge on the basis of insufficient evidence. A jury retired at the end of a week-long trial and cleared him of the second charge. The prosecution said the steward was responsible for banking the Buckley Conservative Club takings, but he failed to bank them properly and a shortfall emerged. When challenged and asked for the paperwork, he said he would provide it to them but never did so, said prosecutor Robert Altham. But Ben Morris, defending, told the jury Griffiths, of Donne Place, Blacon, Chester, denied any dishonesty. He had never taken any of the club\'s money and was not responsible for the shortfall. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964892

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Disabled take to streets in fight for their rights
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline DOZENS of disabled people took part in a march through Chester to raise awareness of issues faced by people with disabilities. Disability groups from Chester and Ellesmere Port took part in the march as part of the disability charity Scope\'s Time to Get Equal Week, which aims to fight discrimination and encourage people to recognise disabled people\'s equality and human rights. Skills co-ordinator at Scope\'s skills development centre in Blacon, Mike Flood, said: "Our march is a direct challenge to the discrimination disabled people face, disablism, and the \'non-human\' way people react when they see disabled people." Scope has released research this week revealing discrimination against disabled people in Chester and the surrounding area, which shows 84 per cent of people in the North West think British society treats disabled people as second-lass citizens. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967465
