properties.name: 20/06/07 - New bid to save Remploy factory
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineNEW hope could be on the horizon for disabled workers threatened with unemployment. The Leader can reveal that plans are being made to put together a consortium of local companies in a bid to save the Remploy plant on Wrexham\'s Railway Road, which employs 79 people. Last month staff were rocked by news that the furniture factory has been included in a list of 33 sites earmarked for closure in the UK. They were told that recent losses meant the plant was no longer sustainable, and that it could close by December, although a rescue could be possible if workers could show how they could keep the plant running with reduced losses. Wrexham MP Ian Lucas is now working to put together a group of businesses from the area which could keep Remploy in the town. He said: "I am very pleased with the responses I have received to date. "It is early days yet, but I have been encouraged by the positive response I have received from across the community to my ideas to save the Remploy site." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967235

properties.name: 20/07/07 - BREAKING NEWS: Two test positive in TB school
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A CHILD and one member of staff have had \'positive readings\' after being screened for TB. The National Public Health Service for Wales has just announced the child and the member of staff, both at Holywell High School, have been referred for further tests after the result. The screening comes after a teacher at the school was diagnosed with TB in June, prompting all those who came into close proximity with the teacher to be tested. Following a screening last week, 208 children and ten members of staff have been given the all clear. One child and one member of staff had positive readings and have been referred for further tests. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047819

properties.name: 20/07/07 - Maelor set for £5 million A&E revamp
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM Maelor Hospital is to spend £5 million in a bid to tackle the massive rise in the number of people being treated in its A&E unit. Work will start tomorrow with the temporary closure of two wards, with further work planned for September and October. Hospital bosses say that in recent years, the number of casualties coming in has risen rapidly, and in 2006/07 about 65,000 people were seen in a unit originally designed for half that number. Corporate support manager Andrew Scotson said: "Inevitably, this sometimes leads to congestion and patients having to put up with long waits for treatment. "However, developments over the next two years will ensure that people coming into the department are assessed on arrival and directed straight to the most appropriate type of care. "So that this can happen, the local GP out-of-hours service will move onto the Maelor Hospital site, the A&E department will be extended, and new short-stay assessment areas will be created where patients can be looked after and kept under observation while tests are carried out." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047555

properties.name: 20/07/07 - Royal couple meet the crowds on city visit
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTAFF and students waved Union Jack flags in a show of patriotism as the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall arrived at the University of Chester. The Earl and Countess of Chester, Charles and Camilla, were greeted in the sunshine as they arrived for a showcase of schemes run by the Prince\'s Trust and the university\'s volunteering work, before attending a ceremony for Charles to receive an Honorary Degree. English language students from Italy, staying on campus during the summer, waved Italian flags alongside Union Jack flags and the couple spent several minutes shaking hands and speaking to the young people. Stephanie Bath, founder of Posh Pickles and Preserves and Posh Bites delicatessen in Frodsham, set up through funding from the Prince\'s Trust. "It was really exciting to meet Prince Charles. He was really nice and so was Camilla," she said. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3047637

properties.name: 20/08/07 - 20-year-old's miracle recovery after holiday hit-and-run
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA YOUNG woman has made a miraculous recovery after she was knocked down by a hit and run driver while on holiday abroad. The incident left Stephanie Arton, 20, from Rhosddu, Wrexham, fighting for her life. She had suffered serious head injuries when she was hit by a car as she crossed the road while on holiday on the Greek island of Zakynthos with her friends, and after flying out to her bedside her parents, Phil and Mary Arton, were told she was minutes from death as blood could not reach her brain. They made the decision for doctors to carry out two operations to save her life. Mr Arton said: "We had 30 seconds to make a decision after being asked – \'do you want your daughter to die or do you risk the operation\'? "You can\'t make a reasoned decision in that time so you have to go for life and hope for the best. "We really thought we were going to lose her." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/20yearold39s-miracle-recovery-after-holiday.3123723.jp

properties.name: 20/08/07 - City Council officer admits stealing £92,000
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA CHESTER City Council officer has admitted stealing more than £92,000 from an organisation that hires out specialist scooters to disabled people. Former principal access officer Timothy Valentine Metcalfe, 44, appeared before Chester, Ellesmere Port and Neston magistrates and admitted stealing £92,000 from Chester Access Group between 2001 and February 2007. He also admitted stealing £210 from the National Federation of the Blind on February 1 and £20 from the same organisation on February 2. The court was told Metcalfe was currently living in temporary accommodation for homeless men at James Lee House, Brick Street, Warrington. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/City-Council-officer-admits-stealing.3124042.jp

properties.name: 20/08/07 - MP Tami's son fights leukaemia
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE young son of Alyn and Deeside MP Mark Tami has been diagnosed with leukaemia. Max Tami, aged nine, was diagnosed with the disease on August 1 after being admitted to Wrexham Maelor Hospital two days earlier. He had been feeling unwell and bruises had started appearing on his skin, so he was rushed to hospital by his worried parents. The couple are now spending all their time at Max\'s bedside at Alder Hey Children\'s Hospital in Liverpool where the youngster was transferred and is receiving chemotherapy treatment. Max is a pupil of Llanfynydd Primary School, where their youngest son, Oscar, is also a pupil. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/MP-Tami39s-son-fights-leukaemia.3123905.jp

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Bank thieves caught after 110mph chase
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO men were captured following a high- speed car chase after a worker tipped-off police. Bernard Byrne, prosecuting, told a court an employee of the Royal Bank of Scotland, in Union Street, Chester, looked out the window at about 7pm one Monday and saw two men outside. Suspicious about their reason for being there, the worker noted their car registration number. A short time later the worker noticed a 42in plasma television was missing from the premises, and assumed the men had taken it. Police were called and the car containing the two men was located travelling along the M53. The driver then accelerated onto the M56 doing speeds of up to 110mph. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2972171

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Dozen patients get breast cancer drug
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline WREXHAM Maelor Hospital has so far provided 12 patients with the breast cancer drug, Herceptin. Hospital bosses say that since the drug was first offered to patients in Wrexham early last year, everyone who has needed it has been given it. Eight of the women who have received Herceptin are new patients. The total cost of prescribing the drug so far is £175,000. North East Wales NHS Trust spokesman Andrew Scotson said: "That is being funded by the Local Health Board. "It needs to be allocated from other areas, or savings need to be found elsewhere, to fund this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968108

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Focus on animals which braved wartime horrors
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineThe bravery of animals during wartime will be highlighted at a talk next week. David Hopkins, co-curator of The Animals\' War exhibition at the Imperial War Museum North (May 26 to January 8), will enlighten visitors to the Grosvenor Museum in Chester about animals in conflict, from the First World War to the present day. Visitors can find out about cavalry horses, mules, elephants, camels, horses and other creatures that have transported soldiers and equipment; the pigeons and dogs who have carried messages; the dogs that have guarded military personnel and property, located injured soldiers, tracked the enemy and sniffed-out explosives, and the animals adopted as official and unofficial mascots and pets by the military. The talk is also a reunion opportunity for members of the Cheshire and North Wales Evacuee Reunion Group and runs from 2-3pm in the museum\'s lecture theatre. Tickets priced £4 (£3 concessions) can be bought from Chester History and Heritage staff on 01244 402110. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971117

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Support floods in for printers devastated by jobs axe
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMESSAGES of support have been flooding in for the families of workers left devastated by major job cuts at a Deeside firm. As the Leader revealed yesterday, about 180 workers at print company Graphoprint, on the Deeside Industrial Estate, have been made redundant after the magazine and catalogue printer went into administration due to financial problems. The company survived a fire in April, 2005 which severely damaged their equipment and premises and last year was bought by print veteran Chris Bramley, with the backing of asset financier CIT Print and invoice discounting company Eurotracker. Administrators KPMG are now seeking a buyer for the company while workers have been told there will be no redundancy payments. One worker, who had been with the company for 20 years, told the Leader: "They must have known the company was in trouble. Why didn\'t they let us know earlier? We\'re not even going to get paid for the last month we have worked. "There\'s guys here like me who have been with this company decades and the way we are being treated is disgraceful. Families are being devastated by this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971546

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Support the zoo's dragons and win an exclusive tour
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER ZOO is giving its loyal supporters a chance to perform a small miracle and win an exclusive behind the scenes tour. The zoo, a conservation charity with over 7,000 animals, is asking its supporters to back its important conservation work through its Small Miracles appeal – and in exchange they will be entered into a prize draw for a behind the scenes tour. The tour will include a special look at Islands in Danger, which is home to the zoo\'s two female Komodo Dragons, Flora and Nessie, and five baby dragons. Flora became an overnight star when she laid a clutch of fertile eggs despite never being mixed with, or mated by, a male dragon. This groundbreaking work with Komodo Dragons is just one of the ways Chester Zoo undertakes its conservation work. The zoo works with over 500 different endangered species, both at home in Chester and in more than 40 countries around the world. Kevin Buley, Chester Zoo\'s Curator of Lower Vertebrates and Invertebrates, said: "None of this work we do would be possible without the support of our visitors and supporters. As a charity we rely on voluntary contributions from people who care about animals to fund our vital work." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968132

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Town's teen abortion rate shock
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM has one of the highest percentages of teenage abortions in Wales, new figures reveal. According to statistics from the Department of Health, more than one abortion a day was carried out in the county borough last year, with 11.8 per cent of them on under-18s. The rate is higher than in many other parts of Wales, and the total number of abortions carried out on women from the Wrexham area is the second-highest in North Wales. The number of abortions carried out on under 18s in Wrexham was higher than those in Cardiff (8 per cent), Swansea (11.6 per cent), Denbighshire (11 per cent) and Flintshire (11.3 per cent). Conwy was named as having the highest number with more than 15 per cent of the total number of abortions being carried out on under 18s. The figures show the overall number of abortions rose in England and Wales from 186,416 in 2005, to 193,737 last year, a rise of nearly four per cent. The previous year, the figures had risen by just 0.4 per cent. Across Wales, 11 per cent of abortions took place at more than 13 weeks into the pregnancy. In this area, Wrexham\'s figures are particularly worrying, according to experts. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971996

properties.name: 21/08/07 - Cement firm told to clean up its act
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCASTLE Cement has been ordered to clean up its act after two fires, dust emissions and a failure to keep to an improvement timetable. The Environment Agency has issued the Padeswood plant with an enforcement notice after an investigation and is even preparing to take the firm to court. The investigation was sparked by a fire on a feeder belt on July 3 that took 14 hours to extinguish. Earlier, on May 14, there was another fire 200ft up the tower involving rubber chippings on a conveyor belt, and dust emissions have been a bone of contention with residents since the £54m kiln went online in July 2005. "Environment Agency Wales has served an enforcement notice on Castle Cement, Padeswood Works, on August 9, for failing to comply with the conditions of its permit," said an EAW spokesman. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Cement-firm-told-to-clean.3126367.jp

properties.name: 21/08/07 - Man dies in Blacon flats plunge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN has died after falling from a block of flats in Chester. The 35-year-old, from Glyn Garth, Nevin Road, Blacon, fell from what is thought to be the 11th floor of the flats complex on Saturday at 3.20pm. Flowers and tributes have been placed on the grass outside bearing a message to "Darren". It said: "Darren, you will be sadly missed by us all. Tracy, Paul, Masin, Jade and Ruby." Police say they are not treating the death as suspicious. Cheshire Constabulary spokesman Glyn Hellam said: "Eight police officers went to the flats at 3.20pm on Saturday after reports someone had fallen. "It would appear a 35-year-old man had fallen from one of the flats and has subsequently died at the scene." Mr Hellam added: "It does not appear to be suspicious and officers are not investigating the circumstances." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Man-dies-in-Blacon-flats.3126986.jp

properties.name: 21/08/07 - Man's fears as bird of prey is found dead
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN investigation has been launched after a valuable bird of prey was apparently electrocuted, after landing on an overhead electricity transformer. Bosses at ScottishPower today confirmed a probe had been launched after the incident on Saturday. Wrexham pensioner Keith Anderson, who has practised falconry since his retirement, is devastated after the second of his birds was apparently killed by an overhead electricity transformer. In 2002, Mr Anderson, 70, of Cefn Mawr, took up the hobby and bought his first bird. A few months later, however, Mr Anderson watched as his owl landed on the high voltage transformer which killed the bird instantly near his home on Mount Pleasant in the village. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Man39s-fears-as-bird-of.3126031.jp

properties.name: 21/08/07 - Teen's head stamped on during rail station attack
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO teenagers have been sentenced – one into custody – for a \'vicious\' attack on a 13-year-old girl. A 16-year-old boy and 15-year-old girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, pleaded guilty to the charge of assault causing actual bodily harm. The attack took place at about 3.15pm on Saturday, March 17, at Wrexham railway station. The victim and another girl, also 13, were waiting on the platform for a train home when they were approached by a group of youths, including the two defendants. After a verbal altercation the female defendant punched the victim in the face. After this initial attack the group walked away and the victim and her friend moved into the waiting room. The group returned, however, and after a further argument, the female defendant resumed her attack on the victim. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Teen39s-head-stamped-on-during.3125982.jp

properties.name: 21/08/07- Jobs boost as store gets set for big reopening
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMORE than 80 new jobs will be created in Wrexham after one of the town\'s major stores underwent a massive new extension. The Tesco Extra store, on Crescent Road, will undergo a first floor extension, creating new jobs and bringing the total workforce at the store to 500 from the local area. The new extension will take the size of the store to 79,000 square feet, making it the biggest Tesco in North Wales. With a week to go before the store officially re-launches, store manager Steve Oliver has announced the recruitment programme has been a great success. The quality of candidates has been very high, with more than 400 applicants for vacant positions. All vacancies have now been filled, from security to counter staff and checkout personnel. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Jobs-boost-as-store-gets.3126207.jp

properties.name: 22/05/07 - Sculptor lashes out at 'flawed' gateway plan
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE giant Postcard design chosen for Flintshire\'s \'Angel of the North\', has been blasted by a Welsh sculptor. Artist David Petersen has branded the winning designs in the Gateway Landmark Wales competition as "appalling" and described the project itself as "fundamentally flawed". The St Clears-based sculptor attacked the winning designs for three huge pieces of artwork to greet visitors to Wales on the A494 in Flintshire, at Holyhead harbour and next to the second Severn Crossing, during a phone-in show on BBC Radio Wales yesterday. He said: "Quite frankly I wouldn\'t like to see any of them. I think they\'re appalling. They are designs by architects. It\'s quite obvious. There\'s very little aesthetic about them at all." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2894755

properties.name: 22/06/07 - Brunstrom's delight as everyone arrives alive
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLINTSHIRE has been singled out for high praise from controversial North Wales Chief Constable Richard Brunstrom, after he revealed there had been no deaths on the county\'s roads in the past year. That is a massive turnaround for the county, which just last year was condemned as having some of the deadliest roads in Wales. A report published by the Wales Centre for Health last summer deemed Flintshire among the worst counties in Wales for road deaths, with the eighth highest number of deaths on its roads, at seven per 100,000. Figures showed in 2004, 62 people were killed or injured on roads in the county, including drivers, passengers and pedestrians. Of these, 26 were under the age of 25. In 2005 eight people died on the county\'s roads, four of whom were males aged 25 and under. In his online blog Mr Brunstrom said with no deaths recorded in the past 12 months, Flintshire and its councillors deserve high praise for cutting out fatalities and that it proved the Arrive Alive partnership, which has had its critics, is proving successful. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2975766

properties.name: 22/06/07 - Man's £15,000 Maelor butty scam
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who fleeced a Wrexham Maelor Hospital charity to the tune of £15,000 has escaped going to jail. Peter Anderson, 48, (pictured) supplied sandwiches to a charity which raises funds by running five cafes for patients and visitors. But he over-charged Maelor Voluntary Services by 100 per cent, Mold Crown Court was told. Judge Dafydd Hughes told Anderson it had been a mean, carefully calculated fraud on a charitable organisation. He had deprived the charity of money which would have been used for the benefit of sick patients. Anderson, of Radmore Road, Liverpool, admitted 15 charges of obtaining money transfers by deception and received a suspended 51-week prison sentence, and was ordered to carry out 150 hours of unpaid work. He produced a banker\'s draft in court to repay the whole £15,000 and now a specialist financial probe into his affairs will be held so a hearing under the Proceeds of Crime Act can take place in September. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2975617

properties.name: 22/08/07 - 'We've been sold down the river' over A494 expansion
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePROTESTERS in Deeside are demanding a senior Welsh Assembly minister take their views seriously when the controversial A494 expansion plans go before a public inquiry. Last week, the Leader revealed that new Deputy First Minister Ieuan Wyn Jones is refusing to abandon plans to turn the A494 into the "North Wales Motorway". It was hoped his appointment, replacing predecessor Andrew Davies, would lead to a review of the plans to turn the road into a seven-lane expressway with a 70mph speed limit and slip roads extending to within feet of people\'s doorsteps. A public inquiry will be held next month. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/39We39ve-been-sold-down-the.3134280.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - Booze leading to more hospital admissions
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE number of people from Wrexham admitted to hospital for drink-related conditions is well above the national average, according to a recent study. Leading doctors in Wales are now calling for more measures to be put in place after the survey by the British Medical Association Wales (BMA). Wrexham was among a number of places in Wales where the emerging drink problem is of particular concern. Staff at Wrexham Maelor hospital have agreed there has been an increase in the number of people admitted to hospital as a direct or indirect result of alcohol consumption. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Booze-leading-to-more-hospital.3138305.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - Council alert police to anti-speeding blogger
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN internet campaign to stop speeding motorists in a quiet village, has landed its author in hot water. From his home, Penyffordd resident Colin Hughes writes an online blog, campaigning against the motorists who speed outside his home on Chester Road, and says Flintshire Council and North Wales Police are doing nothing to solve the problem. But so vociferous have been his attacks on what he sees as the council\'s lack of action, the blogger has been reported to North Wales Police by the local authority. The council\'s acting director of environment and regeneration, Dave Faulker, posted a response on Mr Hughes\' site saying the council will no longer tolerate his website and emails which were being sent to the authority\'s headquarters in Mold. One recent posting on Mr Hughes\' Penyffordd and District Blog used a mock-up of a national newspaper to attack the council and its officers. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Council-alert-police-to-antispeeding.3137234.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Police blitz: Boozy teens face breath test
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM teenagers caught boozing in the streets could be given breath tests by police to discover just how much they have been drinking. As part of a new police operation in the town, underage drinkers will be offered the test in a bid to hit home the dangers of consuming alcohol at an early age. News of the new scheme, Operation Virulent, comes as a survey revealed the number of people being admitted to hospital in Wrexham as a result of drinking is well above the national average. The breath test will provide a reading that will show how much the person has had to drink. It is hoped the move will help to educate young people by showing the level of impairment. The reading can also be provided to the parents of those tested, so they will be able to address the issue at home and avoid the legal system. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/HAVE-YOUR-SAY--Police.3136732.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - Residents' outrage as store's builders close footpaths
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineRESIDENTS in Holywell are furious at the closure of footpaths from a popular tourist spot to the town centre, and say it could have a damaging effect on tourism. Since construction began early this month on the new Tesco site in Holywell, two well-used footpaths and an underpass adjoining the site have been closed until the building is completed early next year. Holywell residents who have helped develop the tourism potential of the Greenfield Valley said there had been no official signage or an apology posted anywhere along the walking trail about the closure of the paths and underpass. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Residents39-outrage-as-store39s-builders.3134704.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - YOUR SAY - City bus wars could see routes axed
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineBUS wars between two rival firms in Chester seem likely to continue for some time. First, which recently took over ChesterBus from the city council, and Arriva, are battling for customers on profitable Blacon and Saughall routes, but there is mounting concern about the future of a number of loss-making services elsewhere in the city which depend on subsidies to keep them running. First is looking to change a number of routes. It is unclear exactly which will be affected, but threatened services include the 35 to Guilden Sutton, 4 to Waverton, 25 to Belgrave Road, Boughton Heath, 28 to Blacon via Saughall Road, and 3 and 3A from Blacon to the Countess of Chester Hospital. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/YOUR-SAY--City-bus.3137509.jp

properties.name: 22/08/07 - Zoo defies weather to pull in more punters
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER Zoo has enjoyed a bumper summer for visitors, despite washout weather. The middle of August saw visitor figures for the year hit the 850,000 milestone. The zoo has reached that target almost a month earlier than it did in the sun-drenched summer of 2006. Last year the 850,000 landmark was not achieved until the middle of September. Head of marketing Sharon Leeson said: "The figures are especially encouraging given all the rain we have had this year. "People continued to flock to the zoo whatever the weather, which confirms what a great attraction we have here." Chester Zoo is already the most popular wildlife attraction in the UK, having welcomed in excess of a million visitors last year. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Zoo-defies-weather-to-pull.3135790.jp

properties.name: 23/05/07 - Boys' graffiti spree inspired by video game
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO "highly intelligent" boys went on a graffiti spree and caused £3,000 worth of damage to buildings in Wrexham, after playing a video game, magistrates have heard. The boys, who cannot be named for legal reasons, spray-painted graffiti nicknames, known as tags, on more than 20 buildings in Wrexham over a four-week period. Wrexham Youth Court heard the 15-year-olds acted completely out of character, came from good homes, were doing well at school and had never been in trouble with the police before. They pleaded guilty to eight offences of causing criminal damage dating from February and March, asking for another 20 similar offences to be taken into consideration. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2897447

properties.name: 23/05/07 - Outrage as factory for disabled faces axe
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORKERS have been left reeling after the closure of a Wrexham factory was announced. Remploy is to close its Railway Road furniture factory, with the loss of 79 jobs. The factory provides specialist employment for disabled people, and is the only branch of Remploy in North Wales. The company says it will work hard to find them alternative employment, but employees have told the Leader they feel they will struggle to find another job. Nicholas Green, who suffers from epilepsy and is a cabinet maker in the plant\'s assembly unit, said the decision to shut the factory was "disgusting". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2898903

properties.name: 23/05/07 - Town hits back over 'uninspiring' label
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE latest edition of a top travel guide has slammed Wrexham as a tourist destination. The new Lonely Planet Great Britain guide has described the town as an "uninspiring" place with "only one real attraction" – Erddig Hall. But the book was full of praise for "lively" and "spectacular" Llangollen. The authors list Plas Newydd and St Collen\'s Church as among Llangollen\'s unmissable attractions, but appears to have ignored many of Wrexham\'s own historic landmarks and tourist sites. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2895876

properties.name: 23/07/07 - Firecrews rescue 11 at fairground
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHERE was drama at Mold Carnival yesterday when eleven people were left stranded at the top of a fairground ride. At 3pm yesterday, firefighters were called to the scene of the Somerfield car park following reports that a fun fair ride, \'The Spritzer\', was stuck. Eleven people were left stuck at the top of the ride. A rescue crew from Mold used a ladder to bring the stranded revellers back to the ground and to safety. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3051196

properties.name: 23/07/07 - Parents' anguish after airman killed in Iraq rocket attack
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A HEARTBROKEN father has spoken of his anguish after his son was killed in Iraq - LEAVE YOUR MESSAGE OF CONDOLENCE Senior Aircraftsman Peter McFerran, of Connah\'s Quay, was one of three servicemen who died at their Basra air base on Thursday. His father Robert said he nearly had a heart attack as he opened cards at his home in Fron Road, Connah\'s Quay, to find that one of them was from son Peter ,22, who perished in a rocket attack. Keep fit enthusiast Peter had been home for two weeks leave last month. Peter and wife Ann had last seen him on June 22 when he returned to Iraq with the RAF Regiment. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3051508

properties.name: 23/07/07 - Teacher and child test positive for tuberculosis
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA CHILD and a member of staff at a Flintshire school have both tested positive for tuberculosis. A teacher at Holywell High School was diagnosed in June, prompting all those who came into close proximity with the teacher to be tested. After a screening last week, 208 children and 10 members of staff received the all clear, but one child and a staff member tested positive. The pair have been referred for further tests, according to the National Public Health Service for Wales. Dr Chris Whiteside, consultant in communicable disease control with the National Public Health Service for Wales, said: "A positive test does not necessarily mean the person has TB. "A positive result can be caused by a reaction to a previous BCG vaccination or to exposure to TB at any time in the past. "It can also be caused by exposure to other germs similar to TB which are mostly harmless. "TB can only be spread by very close contact. The risk of it spreading within the school is very low." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3051096

properties.name: 23/08/07 -  Chester pupils celebrate GCSE success
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHERE were high spirits all round as youngsters got their GSCE results at schools in and around Chester today. At Bishops\' High School, Boughton Heath, the overall pass rate topped the national average and made a school record with 60 per cent of pupils achieving five or more A*-C grades, including maths and English. Headteacher Robert Haigh said: "In a year of very good all round departmental performance and a large number of very strong individual pupil achievements, 96 per cent of Year 11 pupils gained at least five A*-G passes. High achievers include Jenna Mecklenburgh, of Upton, who scored seven A* and two As, Stephen Hodkinson, of Huntington, who got five A*s, four As and one B, and Kate Shone, of Hoole, who achieved five A*, three As and one B. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Chester-pupils-celebrate-GCSE-success.3141617.jp

properties.name: 23/08/07 - GCSE results delight for Flintshire's pupils
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePUPILS across Flintshire were picking up their GCSE results today. Across the county, pupils begun arriving at school from 8.30am to open their results and to see if they got the grades they wanted. And after an excellent performance by Flintshire\'s A-level pupils last week, more good results are expected. High achievers at the Alun School in Mold were Laura Hannington and Jack Wyatt, who both achieved 10 A*s and two A grades. The school achieved a 70 per cent A*-C pass rate, while two thirds of the Year 11 pupils achieved five or more higher grade passes. Alun School headteacher Paul Mulraney said: "It is a fitting tribute to all the hard work that they have done with their teachers over the past five years, and indeed prior to this in our primary schools." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/GCSE-results-delight-for-Flintshire39s.3141183.jp

properties.name: 23/08/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Safety plans for Flintshire's most dangerous road
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineACTION is finally to be taken to improve a road labelled the deadliest in Flintshire. The Leader can today reveal that Flintshire Council is taking action at the notorious Smithy Lane/Oakenholt Lane crossroads on the B5126 Northop to Connah\'s Quay road where, in the last seven years, there have been five fatalities – an average of one every 16 months. The accident blackspot has also been the scene of many other crashes which have resulted in serious injuries. The Leader first reported the story last year and local councillor Tony Sharps has long campaigned for action to be taken before there is another fatal accident. His campaign was backed by Connah\'s Quay man George Smith, a former police officer with more than 20 years experience in dealing with road accidents and fatalities. The council has now agreed to erect speed activated signs which flash when a motorist is driving too fast – seen as an alternative to speed cameras – and to create another lane for right-turning traffic. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/HAVE-YOUR-SAY--Safety.3143225.jp

properties.name: 23/08/07 - Police swoop in Wrexham drugs blitz
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE stormed three properties and made a number of arrests after complaints of drug dealing in an area of Wrexham. The latest raids in Caia Park come on the back of a series of crackdowns by police on the estate. They have been targeting those who supply class A drugs in the community for a number of months. Sgt Alun Oldfield, of Wrexham Police Station, said: "Officers from Wrexham Neighbourhood Policing Team carried out three search warrants under the Misuse of Drugs Act in the Caia Park area of Wrexham. "Quantities of controlled substances were recovered and seized from a number of addresses and a number of arrests were subsequently made. "This is all part of an ongoing initiative throughout the division to catch and convict people who supply controlled drugs." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Police-swoop-in-Wrexham-drugs.3140766.jp

properties.name: 23/08/07 - Wrexham pupils celebrate record GCSE results
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM pupils have helped the town record its best ever year for GCSE results. The percentage of pupils gaining passes with 5 A* - C grades stands at 51.4 per cent, which is the highest ever figure achieved by the County Borough and an improvement of 1.7 per cent on last year\'s seven per cent rise. For many young people, this point marks the end of their school life as they make their way into the world of work. For others it is a stepping stone towards A-levels and higher education. Early indications show that Wrexham schools have, once again, attained great results in a wide range of subjects. Pupils throughout the county have emulated the success of their A-level counterparts last week and a number of Wrexham schools have also reported an improvement on the GCSE results of previous years. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Wrexham-pupils-celebrate-record-GCSE.3140703.jp

properties.name: 24/05/07 - Gun drama at nature reserve
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline ARMED police were called to a nature reserve after a group of youths were reported wielding guns. The incident happened at Maes-y-Pant Nature Reserve, near Gresford, where local campaigners claim protected species of birds have been found shot dead or injured. Police were alerted to the latest incident by Mike Griffiths, a member of Maes-y-Pant Action Group and North Wales Wildlife Trust, when he was warned by dog walkers that a group of young men had been spotted carrying firearms. One frightened women told Mr Griffiths they had seen up to 10 youths, five of which were clutching air rifles and shotguns. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2903263

properties.name: 24/05/07 - Sick thieves run riot at charity office
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineHEARTLESS burglars have ransacked a small charity office which supports elderly people. Shotton-based Wellcheck Flintshire should have been celebrating its second anniversary this week, but instead, shocked workers are counting the cost of the damage, after offenders smashed a window and raided the office, causing damage totalling about £8,000 – leaving the future of the project in jeopardy. After squeezing through the tiny 40cm by 54cm window on Monday night or early Tuesday morning, they proceeded to steal six laptop computers and £20 in petty cash, rip out the alarm and telephone cables and scatter paperwork from filing cabinets all over the floor of the Chester Road West office. The offenders even stole a £30 collection that had been started for a former Wellcheck worker who had lost her sister, and had the nerve to sit and enjoy a take-away burger and soft drinks before using the toilet. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2903393

properties.name: 24/07/07 - Couple's 70-year marriage
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA COUPLE are looking forward to celebrating their platinum wedding anniversary next week. Elvet and Jean Cartwright, from Ruabon, were married at Trinity Chapel, Acrefair in July 31 1937. Mr Cartwright was employed at Hafod Brick Yard before being posted to Norway during the war, and then worked at Monsanto until his retirement. Mrs Cartwright worked as a house maid and then a school dinner lady. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3052123

properties.name: 24/07/07 - Eisteddfod programme just the ticket to smash sales records
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineLLANGOLLEN\'s International Musical Eisteddfod smashed its box office record, organisers have revealed. Despite inclement weather posing problems for organisers, culture vultures were not deterred, snapping up tickets for the star-studded programme of events. Eisteddfod chiefs have released provisional figures showing £580,000 was raised from ticket sales, the highest in the event\'s 61-year history. The takings were 11.5 per cent up on last year, and 44 per cent up on the figure for 2005. This year\'s Eisteddfod boasted sell-out concerts by Joan Baez, Jose Carreras and Hayley Westenra, and although the weather threatened to dampen spirits, audience numbers for daytime and evening events at the pavilion rose by three per cent. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3052196

properties.name: 24/07/07 - Fishermen's invention could stop global warming
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHREE Flintshire fishermen claim to have invented a device to help reduce global warming. The trio say their "Greenbox" will cut all car emissions and convert harmful CO2 gases into biofuel. But despite the global benefits of the invention they are struggling to get support from the Welsh Assembly or the Government. When fitted inside a car boot, the Greenbox stops all greenhouse gases from exiting through the exhaust and stores them in a reusable cartridge. As well reducing exhaust emissions to harmless vapour, the cartridge can be removed and the CO2 fed into a genetically-modified algae farm, which in turn produces a methane bio-fuel. Organic chemist Dr Derek Palmer and engineers Ian Houston and John Jones, who have ploughed £170,000 of their own money into developing the Greenbox, say it could potentially be scaled up to cut all emissions from HGVs and even power stations. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3053810

properties.name: 24/08/07 - A Millennium Stadium for North Wales
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE final design and plans for the redevelopment of Wrexham FC\'s football stadium could be submitted to council chiefs within the next two weeks. Club bosses have revealed that they expect to send the revised plans for The Racecourse to Wrexham Council in the middle of September. Those plans include proposals for the rebuilding of the Kop stand at the Mold Road stadium, which club bosses have confirmed will have up to 5,000 seats. This will mean The Racecourse will, in time, have a 15,000 all-seater capacity, boosting the campaign to turn the stadium into "the Millennium Stadium of the North". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/A-Millennium-Stadium-for-North.3144902.jp

properties.name: 24/08/07 - Police probe after terrifying car blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMYSTERY surrounds a dramatic three-vehicle crash on Manor Industrial Estate, Bagillt, which left a car on its roof and engulfed in flames. A passing photographer captured these amazing images of firefighters desperately trying to contain the flames leaping out of the upturned car. The crash happened shortly after 11pm on Saturday, but police are unsure as to what happened as none of the drivers involved were at the scene when officers arrived. They are now trying to trace the driver who escaped the burning wreck. Fire crews spent several hours at the scene as there was a risk of the fire spreading to nearby gas cylinders. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Police-probe-after-terrifying-car.3145289.jp

properties.name: 24/08/07 - Traders fume over city market
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePROFITS at more than 20 pubs and shops have been hammered by a continental market in Chester city centre, angry traders say. Businessmen and women in and around Northgate Street, including indoor market stallholders, say three weeks of the International Food and Drink Festival have left their bank balances severely depleted, and they have protested to the council and their MP. Outdoor markets have been allowed in Town Hall Square for some years, but permission was given some months ago for a festival running from August 10 until tomorrow. As Town Hall Square is now fully licensed, a beer stall was allowed to trade, provided people sat down and drank from plastic glasses. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Traders-fume-over-city-market.3145663.jp

properties.name: 25/05/07 - Appeal for calm after bird flu outbreak
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineREASSURANCES are being made that the outbreak of bird flu in North Wales currently has no implications for the people of Wrexham and Flintshire. Two people are currently undergoing tests after being taken ill at the smallholding where a case of the disease was confirmed yesterday (May 24). A 1km restriction zone remains in place around the site near Corwen, in Conwy. The "low pathogenic" H7N2 strain of bird flu was found in dead chickens on the farm, which is different from the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain currently circulating in Asia It is the first confirmed outbreak of bird flu in Wales. Full story: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2906147

properties.name: 25/05/2007 - Town industrial estate hit by blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFIREFIGHTERS tackled a blaze at Wrexham industrial estate for more than four hours early today (May 25). Six pumps attended the fire, involving a large quantity of wood in a compound, after receiving a call at 2.51am. An area ladder platform was also used by North Wales Fire and Rescue Service. Firefighters were still at the scene this morning. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2906951

properties.name: 25/07/07 - BREAKING NEWS – U-turn: Cancer mum to get treatment
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline HEALTH bosses have agreed to fund a lifesaving transplant operation for a Wrexham mum who had been told she could not be treated because she lived in Wales. In a dramatic u-turn, the Health Commission Wales have agreed to fund bone marrow transplant treatment for Hodgkin\'s lymphoma sufferer Samantha Cousins, 34. The Leader has followed the story of the Johnstown mum of two, whose doctors at the prestigious Christie\'s hospital in Manchester recommended she should have the transplant, only to be met with a funding refusal by the Welsh Assembly Government body. Meanwhile, patients treated at the hospital under similar circumstances, but who lived elsewhere in the UK, were being funded. The story provoked an outpouring of anger and sympathy from our readers, and Samantha\'s case was taken up at the Assembly by her AM, Karen Sinclair. This afternoon, she has been informed that following an urgent review, the funding will be provided. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3055089

properties.name: 25/07/07 - Bone marrow transplant puts Caitlyn on road to recovery
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA BRAVE girl who has battled with leukaemia for years, is near to leading a normal life after a successful bone marrow transplant. Caitlyn Edwards, seven, underwent a bone marrow transplant at Alder Hey Children\'s Hospital, Liverpool, on May 25. She was first diagnosed with leukaemia in 2003 and underwent gruelling treatment until September 2005, when she enjoyed 15 months of remission before relapsing last December. Now Caitlyn is recovering at home in Sandy Lane, Garden City, where she is cared for by mum Anne-Marie Brown, dad Alan, sister Stephanie and brother Ethan. "The actual transplant went fantastically well," said Anne-Marie. "She got results after day 12, which we weren\'t told to expect until three weeks, so it\'s been excellent. "Blood was taken daily to see what was happening and by day 12 it was showing good results for a few days running. It\'s fabulous, she\'s done fantastic and she\'s really well in herself. "She was so fab in hospital, good old Caitlyn." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3059439

properties.name: 25/07/07 - Fury as vandals damage historic packhorse bridge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineVandals have damaged a historic bridge. A passer-by noticed coping stones had been pulled from the Packhorse Bridge, Caergwrle, and possibly dumped in the river. There is no indication who was responsible for the damage. Community councillor Cliff Shone said: "I am very concerned about this. I will get it sorted out immediately. "The county council spent £20,000 to bring the bridge to its former state after the flood in 2000. "It took down all seven of the arches, which were carefully restored. "It has been maintained since that time. It used to be used by people from the other side of the mountain to come to and from church." Cllr Shone added: "People in this village know how precious it is and they cherish it. "That bridge is our heritage and is very important to the village. "It is a vital link between Hope and Caergwrle. We don\'t know what will happen if it gets damaged again. I will get the police on to it." Hope community councillor Dave Healey was shocked to learn coping stones from the bridge had been removed and apparently thrown into the River Alyn. Cllr Healey, who is also chairman of Hope and Caergwrle Heritage and Conservation Society, said: "The bridge is more than 300 years old and is one of the best examples of its type in Wales. "It was repaired in 2000 following flood damage, but the stones that have been removed are some of the ones belonging to the original bridge itself." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3059467

properties.name: 25/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Mosquito swarms infest villages
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineRESIDENTS on the outskirts of Wrexham have been plagued by swarms of mosquitoes getting into their homes. The problem has got so bad in Rossett the local pharmacist says it is the worst he has seen in his 23-year career. Glen Thompson, of Rossett Pharmacy said: "There have been huge numbers of people complaining about bites. "It\'s the worst case I\'ve ever seen, anywhere I\'ve worked, in my 23 years on the pharmacist\'s register. "Treatment depends very much on the severity of the bite, but the first thing to use would be an antiseptic spray immediately after being bitten. "Later on I\'d probably recommend non-drowsy anti-histamine capsules, but in the worst cases I\'d say to consult your doctor or pharmacist." The latest swarm comes only days after Wrexham town centre was invaded by thousands of flying ants. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3057274

properties.name: 26/07/07 - A494 rethink hopes rise due to shake-up at the Assembly
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePROTESTERS battling against plans to expand the A494 have been given fresh hope after a shake-up at the Welsh Assembly. The new coalition government has resulted in a reshuffle of the cabinet, with the new Minister for Transport, Ieuan Wyn Jones, leader of Plaid Cymru, replacing Labour\'s Andrew Davies. Mr Wyn Jones is now facing calls to take immediate action on the plans to turn the A494 into a seven-lane expressway. The plan to widen the dual carriageway, which have attracted bitter criticism from residents in Aston and Ewloe, was the brainchild of Mr Davies, who said it would be vital for the future of Flintshire. The proposals have been met by a wave of opposition from residents who have dubbed it the "North Wales Motorway" and say it will create a health hazard. After recieving more than 2,000 letters of objection Mr Davies agreed to hold a public inquiry, due in September. The Assembly has said that regardless of the inquiry\'s outcome the final decision on whether the project is given the green light rests with Andrew Davies, but the appointment of Mr Wyn Jones is likely to change that. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3061634

properties.name: 26/07/07 - Health park homes plan gets go-ahead
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline  CONTROVERSIAL plans for nearly 200 homes on disused land on the Countess of Chester Health Park have finally been given the go- ahead by the city planning board. In October 2005, permission to develop on the land was allowed by the Liberal Democrat/Labour town hall administration. The new Conservative administration has been accused by Chester MP Christine Russell of attempting to stall the detailed proposal for the homes, 80 of them classed as "affordable" and for first time buyers. But yesterday, after a lengthy discussion, plans to build the homes and business space on the site, off Liverpool Road, Upton, were given the green light by city councillors who voted a 9-4 majority. Upton Grange Conservative Hilarie McNae said: "We\'re not querying whether there will be a development. We\'re not querying affordable housing, we just need to make sure the development is of a very high quality, something everybody will be proud of." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3062447

properties.name: 26/07/07 - Super Council all set to run our city
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCAMPAIGNERS for one local authority to be responsible for all council services in Chester are today toasting their success. People who have fought for years for unitary government have finally succeeded. New cabinet member Hazel Blears, from the Government\'s Department for Communities and Local Government, had decided a Chester and West Cheshire Council will be set up to replace Cheshire County Council and the six district local authorities serving the county, including Chester City Council. In opting to create West Cheshire and East Cheshire all-purpose councils, Salford MP Mrs Blears, who studied law in Chester, has rejected the County Hall bid for a unitary Cheshire County Council covering an expanse from Parkgate in the west to Poynton, on the outskirts of Manchester, to the east. Chester City and Ellesmere Port and Neston Borough councils have long fought for a unitary council covering both their patches but the new West Cheshire Council will also embrace the Vale Royal Borough Council area of Helsby, Frodsham, Tarporley, Northwich and Winsford and the villages in between. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3063439

properties.name: 26/07/07 - University backs councillor's call to close city's subways
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineUNIVERSITY leaders are backing a councillor\'s call for Chester\'s subways to be shut. County Cllr Peter Byrne, who represents Chester city centre, says the time has come for the subways to be closed once and for all. He wants the subways, particularly the one at the Fountains Rounabout at the top of Northgate Street, to be replaced by pedestrian Puffin and Toucan crossings. Cllr Byrne has tabled a motion calling for action from the county council\'s highways department and the University of Chester is supporting his call. Thousands of students use the Fountains Roundabout subway to make their way from the university campus in Cheyney Road/Parkgate Road to the city centre. Dean of students, Dr Lesley Cooke, said: "The University of Chester would strongly support measures to close Chester\'s subways and replace them with pedestrian crossings. "We believe an \'overland\' alternative to the subway under the Fountains roundabout would be a safer option for the staff and students who use it on a regular basis. "The guidelines provided by the university\'s Student Support and Guidance Department advise students to walk in well-lit and well-populated areas." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3059818

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Eisteddfod: This freak weather won't beat us
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineINCESSANT summer rain has seriously affected the plans for this year\'s National Eisteddfod in Mold but organisers say they are doing everything they can to ensure the show goes on without a hitch. Organisers are meeting daily to thrash out contingency plans to make sure the festival, on Mold\'s Pentrehobyn Estate, goes ahead as planned. The torrential rain which has hit Flintshire this summer, has sparked fears of a washout and the land earmarked for parking could be too wet to use. The Eisteddfod\'s chief executive, Elfed Roberts said the organisers were doing everything they could to seek out alternative parking provision. He said: "We have meetings often with North Wales Police deputy chief constable Clive Wolfendale and other police officers. "We had an extra meeting yesterday which he chaired to discuss the Eisteddfod plans in the light of the poor weather. "We had a discussion about plans and we decided we will continue to talk often with the police and Flintshire Council to look at all options." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3066359

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Flintshire footballer faces big match midfield battle – with Becks
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FORMER pupil from Hawarden High School is set to play against David Beckham and his new team LA Galaxy in the USA next month. Andy Dorman, 25, from Ewloe, has played for Boston US soccer team New England Revolution for the past three years after completing a football scholarship at Boston University. Now one of the top goalscorers for his team, despite being a midfielder, many teams have shown interest in him from the UK, USA, South America and Holland. Andy and his team are due to play against Beckham and LA Galaxy on August 12 and mum Lynne and dad Dennis are making sure they will be there to cheer him on. They fly out next week to spend a month with Andy and his youngest brother Richy, who is following in Andy\'s footsteps and is in the process of doing his own football scholorship at Boston University. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3065663

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Fury as school faces axe
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline GOVERNORS and parents at a city centre school threatened with closure have been dealt another major blow. They blasted the County Hall decision-making process after the ruling executive again voted to shut Boughton St Paul\'s Nursery and Infants\' School next year. Brenda Hughes, a grandparent of one pupil at the school and chairman of the Parents, Teachers and Friends Association, said after a county council executive meeting yesterday: "We think the process is biased and the councillors don\'t represent a cross-section of parties. "They are all Conservatives and not from the area." One parent, who did not wish to be named, said at the end of the meeting: "This is not democracy. It\'s a sham. "I do believe in the Transforming Learning Communities review. They have got to cut costs, but I think it should have been done in a more honest and democratic way." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3066437

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Huge reader debate over strange lights in the sky
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE sighting of strange lights above Wrexham has sparked a massive debate as to whether the UFO claims are genuine or an elaborate hoax. Possible explanations are being put forward to identify the flying objects. Residents in Borras Park reported sightings of seven red lights in the early hours of Wednesday morning. Lynn Jones, 32, recorded one of the lights, which is now on the Leader website. Residents from Borras, Gwersyllt, Caergwrle and Acton said they also saw the lights and cannot explain them. Readers have posted comments suggesting the shape was a cigarette end or a street light. One person believes the video was staged with a lazer pen on a black carpet. Another Borras resident said they could remember a series of UFO sightings over Borras Airfield 20 years ago, mentioning they had seen green lights similar to the ones in the video over the by-pass a year ago. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3065718

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Massive cash deal for Reds
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM FC bosses have today revealed a major new sponsorship deal with one of the UK\'s best known breweries. The club unveiled the deal, reputed to be worth a six-figure sum to the League Two outfit, with Marston\'s. Subject to board approval, the brewery has agreed to sponsor the Mold Road Stand, at The Racecourse, for the next five years. Formerly the Pryce Griffiths Stand, after the ex-Wrexham FC chairman, the name was changed last year. Marston\'s will also be supplying the club with beer as part of the deal. Wrexham FC chairman Nev Dickens was delighted to unveil Marstons as the new sponsors. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3066043

properties.name: 27/07/07 - Zulus in Chester Zoo
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineVISITORS to Chester Zoo flocked to see an energy-sapping routine by one of the world\'s hottest dance troops. The Mighty Zulu Nation Theatre Company have been defying the depressing deluges which have swamped out the British summer so far with a colourful and vibrant daily music and dance spectacle, performed somewhat ironically on the zoo\'s Ark lawn. Their powerful traditional dance moves, accompanied by pulsating Zulu drums and singing harmonies have kept zoo audiences spellbound, inspiring a sea of sunny smiles no matter what the weather. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3063079

properties.name: 28/05/07 - Anti-graffiti partnership beginning to reap rewards
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWrexham Community Safety Partnership is cracking down on graffiti in the town centre – thanks to new cameras and help from the Leader. The two 15-year-olds who recently caused £3,000 worth of damage throughout Wrexham were picked up thanks to anti-graffiti operation Gazump, which is being headed by Insp Chris Beasley. The operation is using digital cameras, funded by the Home Office, which have been given to all 56 Police Community Support Officers in the town and are soon to be given to all School Liaison Officers. The operation asks all officers to take photographs of any graffiti they come across and the photographs are then used to spot reoccuring nicknames or “tags”. If the police spot the same nickname being used repeatedly throughout the area they then put a piece in the Leader appealing for anyone who knows who it might belong to. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2907405

properties.name: 28/05/07 - Trust in turmoil at Reds' plans
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSupporters group split over redevelopment proposal WREXHAM Supporters\' Trust is in turmoil after members made proposals which its board and Racecourse bosses say could have serious implications for the financial future of the club. The planned redevelopment of the ground is the main bone of contention which threatens to split the trust, formed to provide a united fans\' front when the football club\'s financial future was threatened in February, 2002. A total of 11 resolutions will be put to the vote at the trust\'s annual meeting on Thursday, June 7. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2909546

properties.name: 29/05/07 - Pensioner told she would lose her home over £3.90
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ELDERLY woman has received a letter threatening to repossess her home over a £3.90 debt. Emily Cartledge, 89, of Caia Park, who says she has never owed anything in her life, received the letter from Wrexham council after a collector failed to turn up to collect a payment. She usually receives a monthly visit from a collector, who picks up £5.20 home insurance. But in March the collector did not come, which put Mrs Cartledge £3.90 in arrears. Soon after, a letter from the council arrived warning her that her house could be repossessed if she did not pay up. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2911222

properties.name: 29/07/07 - OAP conned by bogus worker
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DISTRACTION burglar claiming to be a water board official duped an elderly Chester resident and stole some money. Chester police have today issued a warning that distraction burglars are operating in the area after the latest incident yesterday afternoon. The police are warning householders to be vigilant following one burglary and an attempted theft yesterday. The first incident occurred at about midday at a property on Meadow Croft in the Saughall area. Cheshire Police spokesman Glyn Hellam said a man called at the home of an elderly man, claiming he was from the water board, and asked to be let inside to check the water. "He entered the man\'s house and said he was turning the water off and went into the kitchen and bathroom," said Mr Hellam. "After he left he realised he had taken a quantity of cash and had been in several rooms." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3066611

properties.name: 30/04/07 - Parent's plea over lifesaving baby unit
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline PARENTS of a baby who survived against huge odds have hit out at the recommendations to close the intensive care unit that saved their son. Jake O\'Connor, now 20 months, was born at 29 weeks, weighing just 2lb 6ozs, on August 4, 2005. He was admitted to the small intensive care unit at the 15-bed special care baby unit at Wrexham Maelor Hospital. If the unit was to close, it would mean premature babies needing intensive care would be taken to Bodelwyddan Hospital, about an hour from Wrexham. To read the full story follow the link http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2840458

properties.name: 30/05/07 - Call for Wrexham Supporter's Trust to re-think relationship with club
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA CANDIDATE for election to the board of Wrexham Supporters\' Trust has hit back at criticism of proposals he put forward to the group\'s annual general meeting. Lindsey Jones, a former member of the board, who resigned earlier this year, is hoping to make a return as part of a group calling for a fresh approach to the trust\'s relationship with the club. He and fellow group members have made proposals which will be debated at the annual meeting, to be held a week on Thursday, and which have drawn criticism from Trust chairman Bruce Clapton. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2913521

properties.name: 30/05/07 - Miracle survival of 23 week baby
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MIRACLE baby, weighing just 1lb 7ozs when she was born at 23 weeks, is now home after being one of the smallest to be born at the Special Care Baby Unit at Wrexham Maelor Hospital. Charlotte Elizabeth Fox has also come off her oxygen mask. Mum Rebecca Fox, 28, of Johnstown, went into labour on Boxing Day after contracting E.coli. Husband Kristian and her parents, Brian and Sue Jones, were worried for both Rebecca and the baby. Doctors kept her in labour for as long as possible but baby Charlotte was born four days later, on December 30. Rebecca\'s father, Brian, who is a grandfather for the first time, said: "When she was born, the odds of her surviving were a million to one - but she came through. "Beccy went into labour on Boxing Day and it was touch and go – Charlotte was born with E-coli as well. We were very concerned for them both. "They wanted to keep the baby as long as they could in labour and gave her steroids to improve her lungs. "The consultant, when he saw Kristian, Rebecca and myself and Sue, pointed out the difficulty in front of her and her survival because she was so small." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2914219

properties.name: 30/05/07 - New training pitch a boost to Reds' future
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWALES football manager John Toshack has officially opened a new facility at Wrexham FC\'s training ground, Colliers Park. The ex-Liverpool legend, who is now trying to steer Wales to qualification for the 2008 European Championships, visited Colliers Park before the national team\'s friendly international with New Zealand at The Racecourse. Accompanied by coach Roy Evans, Toshack cut the ribbon at Wrexham\'s Field Turf training pitch. The artificial pitch is at the forefront of sports technology and is regularly used by Wrexham\'s players when they train at Colliers Park. Toshack said: "It really is super. If you are standing 10 or 15 metres off it, it looks like the real thing. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2914373

properties.name: 31/05/07 - Attack in street left one man in hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline POLICE are investigating an attack by up to 10 people, which left one man in hospital, after a dispute over a cigarette. The incident in Rossett involved a group of four men who were walking along Chester Road. They noticed four unknown young men walking in front of them and another group walking behind. One of the unknown men approached the group of four and asked for a cigarette, and when the request was refused the men were subjected to what police believe was an unprovoked attack. During the attack, one of the four men sustained a broken jaw and needed hospital treatment. Two of the other men suffered cuts and bruises to their face and head, while the fourth man managed to run from the scene. The offenders are described as a group of about eight to 10 people aged between 14 and 25. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2918229

properties.name: 31/05/07 - New inspector to pound the beat on Deeside
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA NEW police inspector has been appointed on Deeside. Darren Wareing, 38, will be based at Connah\'s Quay police station. After starting his police career in Mold 15 years ago, Insp Wareing, has worked all over the region. He was promoted to sergeant six years ago and became an Inspector in 2003. Insp Wareing is taking over from Insp Sacha Hatchett, who has left after 16 months. He said: "I asked to come over here and as part of my commitment I will stay for a minimum of two years." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2916451

properties.name: 31/05/07 - Protesters celebrate after plan for 131 homes rejected helps overturn link road plans
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineHomeowners in Buckley who staged a protest against plans for 131 new homes in the town are celebrating after the scheme was thrown out by councillors. The demo was held outside Flintshire Council\'s headquarters in Mold before the authority\'s planning committee decided on the project, which involved a link road the objectors said would become a dangerous \'rat run\'. Councillors unanimously rejected the development, to the applause of the public gallery. Buckley Mountain Cllr Carol Ellis, who has long fought against the plan, said: "Common sense has prevailed. I am strongly against the development and the details. There is already a lack of green space in the area without this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2918454

properties.name: 31/05/07 - We'll fight to save our factory
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineDISABLED workers at a factory earmarked for closure have vowed to fight for their futures after being thrown a potential lifeline by company bosses. Last week staff at the Remploy furniture factory on Wrexham\'s Railway Road were rocked by the shock announcement that the plant could close as early as December this year. The factory\'s 79 employees were left fearing for the future, with many telling the Evening Leader they did not believe they would find work elsewhere. However, their hopes have been raised after what has been described as a "productive" meeting yesterday when company bosses met union leaders, workers and politicians to discuss the closure plans. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2918316

properties.name: 31/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Disgust as vandals damage churchyard again
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA grave which was desecrated by mindless vandals on a churchyard wrecking spree has been targeted again. Last month, the Leader reported on an attack at St Giles Parish Church, Wrexham, which saw a 19th Century vault in the grounds seriously damaged. Rector Canon Geoffrey Marshall and church volunteers spoke of their disgust and anguish over the incident, which threatened to leave the church with a hefty repair bill. The above-ground, tomb-like part of the grave was shattered, in what was suspected to have been a hunt for a body. Now, despite CCTV cameras monitoring the yard for persistent troublemakers, the vandals have struck again. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3071958

properties.name: 31/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - New era for city
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORK in finally under way on the most important transformation of Chester city centre for decades. The first major demolition work, heralding the beginning of the £40 million Northgate Development project, has begun. City council leader, Cllr Margaret Parker, was behind the controls of a large digger, a Komatsu PC 600, as it ripped into the landmark St Martin\'s House, at the back of Chester Bus Station. The former health authority building, fronting the inner ring road, has been vacant for more than a decade and become an eyesore. The interior fittings and fixtures, windows, doors and asbestos have been removed and the digger, operated by demolition firm KDC, will take about three weeks to bring down the building. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3073471

properties.name: 31/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - Residents protest over skate park plan
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline   PRESSURE is being mounted on councillors to reject controversial plans for an award-winning skate park plan. Scores of residents turned up at Wepre Park yesterday to confront community leaders and try to change their minds about the park. Councillors who arrived by coach were met with furious protests from householders concerned about the welfare of their local beauty spot and the risk of hazards to children and anti-social behaviour in their community. Over 850 residents have signed a petition objecting to the Quay Wheels project, which will be put before Flintshire County Council\'s planning committee tomorrow. Last year Quay Wheels earned funding totalling £60,000 after a nail-biting TV vote on ITV Wales. Judges said the project caught the \'hearts and minds\' of viewers. When the project secured the funding, Connah\'s Quay town centre manager Lisa Fearn said: "This will be a fantastic facility for Connah\'s Quay and the whole of Flintshire." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3072404

properties.name: 31/07/07 - HAVE YOUR SAY - £9million shake-up for county schools
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MASSIVE £9m shake-up of Flintshire\'s special schools is expected to be given the green light this week. Plans to close three special schools, Ysgol Delyn, Mold; Ysgol Belmont, Buckley; and Ysgol y Bryn, Shotton; and replace them with a primary school attached to Gwynedd Primary School, Flint, and a secondary school attached to Flint High School, have been recommended for approval. Flintshire Council planning committee meets on Wednesday and is expected to give the plans formal approval, resulting in one of the biggest shake-ups of educational provision for children with learning difficulties in the county\'s history. The council says the move will mean it can provide better levels of education for its pupils and also benefit youngsters in mainstream schools. However, the plans have not been without controversy, with some parents claiming their children will be victimised by relocating to a mainstream site, and some councillors attempting to block the move by claiming it will create huge upheaval for parents who now will have to transport their children to Flint. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3070517

properties.name: 31/07/07 - Landlord beaten in crowbar attack
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineINTRUDERS beat a Flintshire man with a crowbar during a violent robbery at his home. Police are hunting three robbers who forced their way into the home of the Hawarden pub landlord, assaulted him, and stole a large quantity of cash and jewellery. They then fled in a stolen silver Vauxhall Cavalier, which was later found burned out. Officers were called to the house on The Wigdale shortly after 11pm on Sunday and deployed the force helicopter to conduct a sweep of the surrounding area, but the men remain at large. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3073399

properties.name: 31/07/07 - Masked raid at village post office
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA POST office owner was threatened by two men wearing balaclavas during a terrifying robbery. Owner Judy Smith has been left in shock after she was threatened during the raid. The two masked men went into the post office in Cymau, near Wrexham, at about 3.30pm yesterday and made off with cash. A Peugeot 406, said to be involved in the incident, was found later in the Brymbo area of Wrexham. The post office was open for business this morning but Mrs Smith, who has been serving the small community for more than 20 years, said what had happened hadn\'t sunk in yet. She said: "They came in, frightened me and then took some cash. The community are all very supportive, it\'s only just sinking in. "I\'ve been here over 20 years and nothing like this has happened before." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3072676

properties.name: 31/07/07 - Wrexham pensioner scoops £100,000 jackpot
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA PENSIONER from Wrexham had one of the luckiest days of her life when she scooped £100,000 at bingo. The woman, who has asked not to be named, was at Mecca, Brook Dale Place, Chester, when she landed the prize – on Friday, July 13. She won the top prize – the National Bingo Game with a £100,000 jackpot – as well as club prize of £226, having completed a "full house" in 41 numbers, the lowest call in 500 clubs playing nationwide. It was also a belated birthday present as she was 69 in June. She joined the Mecca Club in 1992 and plays three or four evenings a week. It is one of the biggest wins for a Wrexham resident in recent years, after a woman from Ruabon won £33,298 at Wrexham\'s Mecca Bingo. Other wins include a £101,000 winner in January, 2005, and a £51,000 winner in November, 2005. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3070180

properties.name: 310/07/07 - Dogs die after they are trapped in house fire
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO dogs died after becoming trapped in a house fire in Deeside on Saturday North Wales Fire and Rescue Service were alerted to the fire at a house in Chester Road, Sandycroft, by Cheshire Fire and Rescue Service, just before 5pm and two crews of firefighters from Deeside went to the scene. The blaze had started in the kitchen of the property and the rest of the home become heavily smoke-logged. Although the occupants were out, fire officers recovered the bodies of two dogs who had been trapped in the house. Paul Scott, station manager at Wrexham said: "Despite the fact there was nobody in the property at the time of the fire there were no working smoke detectors. Had there been, neighbours might have been alerted to the fire much sooner." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3069769
