properties.name: American-style bid to pick Tory candidate
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAMERICAN-style election tactics will be used to pick the Tories candidate for the marginal seat of Chester at the next General Election. An Open Primary will be used to pick the prospective Parliamentary candidate, and members of the City of Chester Conservative Association will be joined by members of the public to choose a candidate on Saturday, September 29. The idea has been branded a "gimmick" by city Labour MP Christine Russell, who will be seeking her fourth term of office but is defending a majority of less than 1,000. The idea of an Open Primary has been used by Conservatives in other parts of the country but never in Chester. At the last General Election it was used in Warrington South where solicitor Fiona Bruce was chosen, but she failed to unseat sitting Labour MP Helen Southworth. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Americanstyle-bid-to-pick-Tory.3194103.jp

properties.name: Birth of lion cub is boost to species
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineHE\'S just a few days old but Tejas, the tiny lion cub, offers a glimmer of hope for his species. The male Asiatic Lion, who is being hand-reared by Chester Zoo\'s carnivore team, was born to mum Asha after a three and half month pregnancy. With between 300-350 Asiatic Lions left in the wild, the little male will make a big difference to the conservation of his species. Asiatic Lions can now only be found in India\'s Gir Forest and 17 lions have been killed there in the last five months. With the number of Asiatic Lions plummeting, Chester\'s new cub will eventually play a major part in a breeding programme for his species, ensuring it continues. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Birth-of-lion-cub-is.3195628.jp

properties.name: Brave shopper foils armed robbers
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineBRAVE shopper intervened to stop an attempted armed robbery in Flint. In the latest of a series of raids in Flintshire, two men, one masked and one wearing a "hoody", tried to steal money from a Tesco Express store in the town on Friday, armed with what appeared to be a metal bar. Detectives are now hunting the two raiders who threatened staff on Friday night. The offenders approached the cashier, lent over the counter and demanded cash from the till. One of the shoppers in the store bravely intervened and held the offender away from the counter. Both offenders then left the store empty-handed and were seen running off in the direction of Oakenholt. A police spokesman said: "Police investigations are already under way and CCTV is being studied as part of the inquiry. Officers are extremely keen to hear from anyone who was in the vicinity of the store at the time and who may have seen the two offenders in the area." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3106010

properties.name: Coroner hits out after death in crowded hospital department
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A CORONER has hit out after a man who was in "obvious distress" and later died was not helped enough despite being in a crowded hospital A&E department. Speaking at an inquest into the death of 60-year-old unemployed lorry driver Tony Butterton, from Cefn Mawr, North East Wales coroner John Hughes said only a security guard and a female patient had tried to help him as he sat slumped in a chair in the packed A&E department. "Everybody else went about their normal business and almost turned their backs on what was happening," said Mr Hughes. Describing it as a "British habit", Mr Hughes said that if it was obvious Mr Butterton was in distress, he would have hoped somebody else would have intervened. Mr Butterton, a father of seven, died in the hospital\'s accident and emergency department on February 18. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Coroner-hits-out-after-death.3193511.jp

properties.name: Eisteddfod 'best in memory' says MP
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMORE than 150,000 descended on Mold last week to celebrate the Flintshire and District National Eisteddfod. The festival attracted crowds of 154,944 according to Eisteddfod officials, up from last year and only just under the Eryri Eisteddfod two years ago. And that figure does not include the evening concerts and events at Maes B, the young people\'s village, and Maes C, the caravan park. The event was held on the Pentrehobyn Estate on the outskirts of Mold and with glorious sunshine allaying fears of a washout sparked by awful weather before the event, it has been hailed as massive success. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3105424

properties.name: Eisteddfod clean-up
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE big clean-up operation has begun in Mold after the finale of the hugely successful Flintshire and District National Eisteddfod. Eisteddfod crew members tackled the camping field on Monday which was strewn with rubbish, broken glass, abandoned tents and even a smashed touring caravan. Crew member Mark Pritchard said: "It\'s a bit of a mess. But it was worth it." His colleague Ed Barkham added: "It was a good festival. But it\'s probably going to take two or three days just to clean this field up." The Maes aftermath is being cleaned up by several groups who will take on various areas of the site over the next week. The Eisteddfod clean-up crew want aim to try and uphold the green efforts of this year\'s festival. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3107823

properties.name: Emergency services in twin rescue drama on River Dee
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DRAMATIC hunt for a man missing from home ended happily when he turned up safe and well – but in a bizarre coincidence, rescue crews also had to save another man threatening to harm himself. The search – involving police, North East Wales Rescue teams, the Search and Rescue Dogs Association (SARDA), coastguard and Flint Lifeboat – began when North Wales Police were alerted at 2.43am yesterday with a report of concerns for the safety and welfare of a 23-year-old man. Last seen at around 1am at his home address in Connah\'s Quay, the missing he was believed to be wearing jeans and a psychedelic green and yellow T-shirt. He was described as being 6ft 1ins tall, of slim build and with dark, short hair. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Emergency-services-in-twin-rescue.3193721.jp

properties.name: Family pays tribute to man killed on holiday
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE family of a man who died after been hit by a car while on holiday in Spain have described him as a "person much loved by all who knew him". Martin Penn, 32, of Pulford, near Rossett, was on the first day of his holiday with three friends when he was hit by a car in Calahonda, near Marbella. The family has said that the four friends will return home together. They made a statement yesterday which said: "Martin died tragically in Malaga hospital at 9am local time yesterday. "There was an accident at around midnight in Calahonda where Martin was hit by a vehicle. "He was treated at the roadside and then taken to Marbella hospital and he was later transferred to Malaga. "Martin was a much loved person by all who knew him. He leaves behind a loving family and countless friends. "The three friends remaining in Spain are staying to assist with his repatriation." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Family-pays-tribute-to-man.3190494.jp

properties.name: Family's brick attack horror
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MOTHER has spoken of the terrifying moment when a brick thrown from the roadside struck her family\'s car. Katie and Stephen Brooks from Rhostyllen were travelling back to Wrexham after a 10-day holiday in Slovakia with children Claire 16, Llinos, five and Cerys, four, in the back of their car. She said: "We had just been away for 10 days and we were travelling back – we had had a really nice time." But, as they drove through Wrexham on their return, the family had no idea what was about to happen. As they drove past the Hightown flats on Kingsmills Road, a brick was launched at the car, hitting the passenger side an inch below the window where the children were sitting. Mrs Brooks, 28 described the experience as "terrifying", and said she feared for the worst. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3108263

properties.name: HAVE YOUR SAY - CCTV to stop 'tombstoning'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineLLANGOLLEN Town Council is introducing CCTV to help in the fight to stop dangerous and anti-social behaviour in the town. On Friday, the Evening Leader reported youths had been videoing themselves jumping from Llangollen Bridge and posting the clips on the Youtube website. A bylaw is currently going through and local councillors are hoping it will work with CCTV, and a law banning drinking on the streets, to stop people jumping from the bridge and the anti-social behaviour associated with it. Ian Parry, clerk of Llangollen Town Council, said: "We are concerned about the safety of the individuals that jump off the bridge as well as the anti-social behaviour of crowds that gather there. "The bylaw will help police to stop this dangerous activity. We have a community safety group in Llangollen, and we\'ve been concerned about these issues for some time. We are currently installing CCTV in the town, and there will be a camera which can pick up the bridge and people jumping off." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3109823

properties.name: HAVE YOUR SAY: City estate's £12 million transformation begins
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA £12 MILLION transformation of a Chester housing estate is finally under way. The demolition phase in Treborth Road, Blacon, has ended and building work will now begin. Nearly 160 new homes are to be built on the estate and properties will be available for rent, shared ownership and sale, providing local families with affordable housing options. Nearby householders have waited for years for the work the go ahead and have witnessed setback after setback. But the work is finally moving forward and Liz Kent, a member of TASC 2000, the Treborth Road Residents Association, said: "Seeing the builders on site is just fantastic. This is great news for our estate and for the future of Blacon. "Everyone is really excited about the changes that are happening." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3105778

properties.name: HAVE YOUR SAY: Council pledge to put pride back in streets
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FLAGSHIP new scheme has been launched to provide a blueprint for a cleaner, greener and safer Wrexham. Pride in Your Streets is a new council scheme aimed at giving residents one easy point of contact to report issues affecting their streets, highways and open spaces. There is now a hotline for residents to ring to report any environmental concerns that may range from graffiti to dog fouling and street lighting, and to mark the occasion, vehicles and council workers held a parade in the town. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/HAVE-YOUR-SAY-Council-pledge.3198594.jp

properties.name: HAVE YOUR SAY: Flintshire super highway probe to cost £15,000 a day
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE cost of the public inquiry into the controversial A494 expansion plans could cost as much as half-a-million pounds, the Leader can exclusively reveal today. Figures obtained by the Leader show the Welsh Assembly has already paid out £180,466 from public funds preparing evidence, rebuttals, staff costs, legal fees and advertising the public inquiry, which started today. The Assembly is also estimating the weekly cost of holding the inquiry at £82,705, and with it expected to last up to four weeks, the overall cost could break the £500,000 barrier. The controversial plans to expand the A494 into a seven-lane expressway, dubbed \'The North Wales Motorway\', have attracted bitter criticism from residents in Deeside who say it will bring horrendous noise, traffic and pollution to their doorsteps. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/HAVE-YOUR-SAY-Flintshire-super.3190794.jp

properties.name: HAVE YOUR SAY: Historical figure takes pride of place
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAJESTIC statue of one of Wales\' most famous sons, Owain Glyndwr, was unveiled in his home town yesterday. The statue\'s unveiling coincides with the 607th anniversary of Glyndwr proclaiming himself Prince of Wales on September 16, 1400, during a rebellion against the English. After four years of planning and development, the life-size bronze sitting astride his horse, was carefully placed in position in Corwen town square yesterday. Sculptor Colin Spofforth from Chester spent two years creating the work, which weighed almost a ton and on its engraved Welsh granite plinth, stands 4.5m high. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/HAVE--YOUR-SAY-Historical.3202636.jp

properties.name: Inquest into flats plunge death halted
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN INQUEST into the death of a woman who fell from the fifth floor of a block of flats in Blacon was halted after a key witness failed to turn up. The hearing into the death of Bronwen Jackson, 54, had to be adjourned in Chester after Stephen Booth did not attend the hearing. Mrs Jackson died after falling from the fifth floor of Glyn Garth, Nevin Road, Blacon, on May 14. The inquest opening at Warrington coroner\'s office in May was told mother of two Mrs Jackson climbed over the balcony edge. A post-mortem examination by Dr Richard Shephard from Liverpool Hope Hospital revealed she died as a result of multiple injuries. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Inquest-into-flats-plunge-death.3194586.jp

properties.name: JOIN OUR FORUM: Bombshell for A494 expansion protesters
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePROTESTERS fighting the proposed expansion of the A494 have suffered a further blow, with Deputy First Minister Ieuan Wyn Jones announcing his preferred route for phase three of the project. With two weeks remaining of the public inquiry into phase two of the development – which proposes a seven-lane highway from Drome Corne to Ewloe – Mr Wyn Jones has sent a letter to residents on Wednesday, announcing he already has a preferred route for phase three. The letter reads: "Mr Ieuan Wyn Jones . . . has announced his decision to on a preferred route for the A55/A494 Ewloe Interchange with a connection to the A494 in Mold and the A55 Ewloe to Northop improvement." The decision left councillors and protesters stunned. Buckley Mountain councillor Carol Ellis said: "We have been waiting since January for this information and the timing leaves a lot to be desired because we have not been able to study the recommendations." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/JOIN-OUR-FORUM-Bombshell-for.3202635.jp

properties.name: JOIN OUR FORUM: Protesters fear council's u-turn over N. Wales motorway
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA SECRET meeting on the eve of the public inquiry into the controversial A494 expansion plans has left protesters reeling. The long-awaited public inquiry into plans to turn the A494 from Drome Corner to Ewloe into a monster seven-lane expressway opened yesterday, and protesters battling to stop it were shocked when it was revealed a meeting between Flintshire Council and Welsh Assembly officials had taken place on Monday. Angry protesters were told the council, which has previously objected to the plans, may now withdraw its opposition. Welsh Assembly representative Milwyn Jarman QC told the inquiry: "Negotiations between Assembly officials and Flintshire County Council took place and as a result, a number of issues have been agreed upon." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/JOIN-OUR-FORUM-Protesters-fear.3193904.jp

properties.name: Kelsall - Conservative
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineKELSALL Hugo Deynem (Con) 843 Nicky Moore (Lib Dem) 778 Ian Stuart Irving (Lab) 90 Majority: 65. Turnout: 60 per cent. (Lib Dem Cllr Joan Fairhurst did not seek re-election).

properties.name: Kitten rescued from scrap metal crusher
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA VERY lucky kitten is recovering after being saved from a pile of scrap metal at a recycling centre. The fortunate feline was rescued at Chester Recycling Centre, and is now being cared for by Cats Protection in Wrexham. Victor Stevenson, a worker at the recycling centre, a collection point for scrap metal, spotted the cat, which has been named Penny because she was so lucky, after hearing a faint cry from the pile. Vicky Keen, adoption centre deputy manager at Cats Protection, said: "Seven week-old Penny is extremely lucky to be alive. "Her remarkable rescue is all thanks to the eagle-eyed Mr Stevenson." In the recycling centre yard, large machinery is in use to move the piles of metal before it is taken away for recycling. Mr Stevenson said: "I heard the faint cry of a cat, and found a tiny kitten wedged in a mound of scrap metal that was ready to be taken away. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3108469

properties.name: Knife raid terror at city store
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMEMBERS of staff at a Chester store were left badly shaken after being threatened with a knife and forced to hand over cash. Store manager of Cool Trader on Sealand Road, Shaun King, and a female assistant were opening up the store in the former Kwik Save store at about 8.30am yesterday when the raiders struck. Cheshire Constabulary spokesman Dave Murray said: "They were approached by two men with a knife. The two males stole a large quantity of cash from the store." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news/Knife-raid-terror-at-city.3202881.jp

properties.name: Landlord's armed gang ordeal
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA LANDLORD beaten unconscious in a terrifying armed robbery believes it is only a matter of time before the gang, who struck at his pub, kill someone. The raid on the New Inn at Pontblyddyn was the sixth armed robbery in Flintshire this month. Staff and locals were enjoying a pint just after midnight on Friday when three masked men, one brandishing a pistol, entered the pub. They immediately beat landlord Dave Hunt over the head with a baseball bat, pushed his wife, Sandra, and the four customers into a corner and screamed orders and abuse at them. Mr Hunt said: "When they first came in, I just didn\'t register it. It was so out of the ordinary. "I was behind the bar and I moved my arm slightly and I can only assume they thought I was going for the alarm. The big one attacked me with a baseball bat. "I fell to the floor and my head was bleeding heavily. I can\'t remember much after that." Mr Hunt\'s wife had been moved into another section of the bar and was unaware of the attack on her husband until the gang ordered her to open the till. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3109101

properties.name: Mum's terror after arson attack on Wrexham flats
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN has spoken of the horrifying moments she feared her daughter would be killed in an arson attack. The Wrexham woman, who asked not to be identified, was among the first people at the scene as fire crews rushed to the blaze in flats on Crescent Close, Wrexham. Her 29-year-old daughter was trapped by the ground-floor fire, which the fire service believe was started deliberately. She said: "It was terrifying. We had been out together on Saturday night and my daughter and a friend had gone back to try on some clothes at the flat. "As I was walking back to my home, which is nearby, I saw the fire engines, but didn\'t know at the time that my daughter was involved." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Mum39s-terror-after-arson-attack.3190416.jp

properties.name: Owen heads bid to get young race fans on board
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA NEW scheme, spearheaded by Flintshire soccer ace Michael Owen, has been launched in a bid to to attract more young people into the world of horse racing. Club ROA is the brainchild of Paul Dixon, the new president of the Racehorse owners\' Association, and is an introduction to the world of racehorse ownership for people aged between 18 and 32. One of the club\'s horses is being trained at the new stables of England and Newcastle United footballer Michael Owen, in Cheshire. In all, four horses will initially run in the club\'s pale blue and yellow colours, with members – each paying just £199 a year – able to watch them on the training gallops and at the races, as well as attending social events around the country. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3110710

properties.name: Police chief calls for society to help beat yobs
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE are waging war on louts and drunks every night of the week, says Cheshire\'s police chief. "Every night of the week Cheshire officers and our PCSOs are engaged in a constant battle against anti-social behaviour and alcohol-induced violence," said Chief Constable Peter Fahy. "More officers on the streets working with the local council has significantly reduced criminal damage and anti-social behaviour but, by any measure, there is still a long way to go. "Across the force area, on estates and in villages, groups of young people gather, sometimes in large numbers, and officers constantly break the groups up, seize alcohol, take names and send letters to parents. When we have evidence, we prosecute. "Parents should be the key to tackling this problem. They are responsible for their children, and that responsibility is not abdicated when they become teenagers. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3112174

properties.name: Putting zoo's animals in the picture
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineARTIST Rosie Rees will share a slice of paradise with an exhibition of her work at Chester Zoo. The zoo\'s diversity of species, from tiny seahorses to giant birds, has been the inspiration behind Rosie\'s exhibition A Painter in Paradise. Rosie\'s artwork has captured a taste of the worldwide biodiversity the zoo brings to its visitors through its 7,000 animals and 200- plus species of plants, including a national collection of cacti and locally endangered Black Poplar. Originally from Shropshire, Rosie, a keen photographer and strong supporter of the zoo, took up the position as the zoo\'s artist in residence in March this year. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Putting-zoo39s-animals-in-the.3191842.jp

properties.name: Python star in city to retrace map maker's steps
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MEMBER of the legendary Monty Python comedy team has been filming in Chester for a new history series. Terry Jones and Ogilby\'s Roads, a documentary for BBC Wales, traces the journeys of map maker John Ogilby – \'Cosmographer to the King\'. Jones, who was born in Colwyn Bay, follows the journey from Chester to Holyhead using a map taken from the book, Britannia, published in 1675. The route takes the traveller from Chester to Anglesey by crossing the Lavan Sands at low tide from Penmaenmawr on the Welsh mainland to a ferry across the strait to Beaumaris. Filming took place at the Groves, the Walls at Bridgegate and the Rows. Terry also grabbed the chance to set sail as he borrowed a peddle boat from Chester Boats for a scene on the Dee. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3110711

properties.name: River rescue after man fled police
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN jumped into the River Dee in a bid to escape the police, prompting a rescue operation by emergency services. Police were called to the Groves area at about 9.20pm yesterday following reports of a group of men causing a disturbance in the area. One of those involved in the incident tried to evade the police by jumping into the Dee and attempting to swim away. Sgt Andy Pickup, of Chester Police, said: "There was one man in particular who was causing trouble but as police arrived he decided to jump in the river and try to swim to the other side to get away and has been dragged out. He injured himself trying to escape and has been reported for a public order offence." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3109114

properties.name: SPEAK OUT: Boy, 7, in gang attack on woman
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE have condemned a gang attack, including a member believed to be as young as seven, that left a middle-aged woman in hospital. Youths assaulted the woman in broad daylight as she walked her dog in the Pandy area of Oakenholt, Flint. The woman, in her 50s, was taken to hospital suffering minor injuries after being assaulted at 16.30pm on Wednesday while walking on the bridal path near Pandy Pond. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/SPEAK-OUT-Boy-7-in.3202714.jp

properties.name: Second hanging death shocks village
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineANOTHER villager has died by hanging near Chester. Robert Cyril Steventon, 48, of The Old Stables, Lime Tree Drive, Farndon, died last Wednesday evening at his home. Deputy Cheshire coroner, Dr Janet Napier, opened an inquest into his death yesterday at the coroner\'s offices in Warrington. A post-mortem examination revealed he died as a result of hanging. Police said the circumstances were not suspicious. The inquest was adjourned for a date to be fixed. Cheshire Constabulary spokesman, Dave Murray, said: "Police got the call at 9.40pm to attend an address on Lime Tree Drive. The body of a 48-year-old male was found." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Second-hanging-death-shocks-village.3191119.jp

properties.name: Tributes after second village hanging
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE partner of a man who hanged himself has paid tribute to a \'truly dear friend and partner\'. Robert Cyril Steventon, 48, of The Old Stables, Lime Tree Drive, Farndon, died at his home last Wednesday. It is the second tragedy to hit the village in two weeks, after a 23-year-old was found hanging from a pub sign. Partner of 10 years, Andy Ecclestone, who lives and works in Wrexham, has told the Leader Robert was his best friend, who will be remembered fondly by his friends, family and locals in the village. He said: "Most people will remember him for walking his two Jack Russells, Burt and Jacks, through the village. Everything revolved around the dogs." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Tributes-after-second-village-hanging.3198424.jp

properties.name: WATCH THE VIDEO: Comic slammed after insulting Wrexham
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA POPULAR comedian has been slammed after making a series of jibes against Wrexham on stage. Footage posted on video sharing website, YouTube, of Rob Heeney on stage at one of a well-known chain of comedy clubs, contains a number of derogatory comments about the town and its people. Originating from Douglas, Isle of Man, Heeney is established as a top comic. During the rant, the comedian says: "I was in Wrexham last week, I\'m not proud of that. It\'s not a great place, they think they are cosmopolitan because they have a KFC." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/WATCH-THE-VIDEO-Comic-slammed.3202353.jp

properties.name: WATCH THE VIDEO: Help Tony win pop crown dream
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA SINGER is asking for people in the area to help him get into the final of a karaoke competition. Tony Birch, from Wrexham, was crowned karaoke king in Blackpool, in the Poppets Pop Pickers Tour competition. The grand final of the tour is about to go live on the web, which means the heat is on for Tony. With the results of the web poll to be announced on September 25, the people of Wrexham are urged to make a difference by voting for the home-grown talent. Tony, a 57-year-old project worker and father-of-three, was visiting Blackpool for the weekend when he stumbled across the competition. He will be competing against 10 other finalists, all clamouring for the chance to be the UK\'s Poppet of Pop. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/WATCH-THE-VIDEO-Help-Tony.3191774.jp

properties.name: WATCH THE VIDEO: Sniffer dog weeds out drug users in Deeside
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DRUG user and disorderly revellers were arrested in two police operations at the weekend aimed at ensuring safe nights out in Deeside. On Friday night, Deeside Inspector Darren Wareing and his team took special guest Molly, a Wrexham-based sniffer dog, and her handler out to five pubs in Shotton, Connah\'s Quay and Queensferry under Operation Basildon. Following indication by Molly, one man was arrested after he was found to be in possession of class C drugs. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/WATCH-THE-VIDEO-Sniffer-dog.3191973.jp

properties.name: Young mum took her own life
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA YOUNG mum took her own life just two months after giving birth to her first child. An inquest heard of the tragedy of how popular Fiona Gilbert, 31, hanged herself on February 12 at the home she shared with partner Nigel Jenkins and their baby daughter Rebecca in Ash Lane, Mancot. She had given birth just two months earlier and her suicide was described as a "terrible waste of a life" by the coroner at the inquest into her death yesterday. Mr Jenkins, now of Firbrook Avenue, Connah\'s Quay, told the Flint inquest he had met Fiona in 2001 and they hit it off straight away. She moved in with him at his home in Aston Meads in Aston and they later lived in Mancot and Hawarden before buying a house together in Mancot. He said they had a brilliant relationship and a good social life. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Young-mum-took-her-own.3198955.jp

properties.name: Zoo show aims to highlight plight of island paradise
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline FUN events have been organised at Chester Zoo aimed at keeping families both entertained and informed over the school holidays. A highlight of the summer programme is a theatre show taking children on an imaginative journey to the exotic shores of Madagascar, the world\'s fourth largest island and one of its most treasured wildlife habitats. Two cheerful costumed characters, Mandrita, the tree boa and Maki, the ring-tailed lemur, lead the action. The adventure-filled tale, called The Family Tree, centres on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar, off south east Africa, once a favourite haunt of pirates and scene of shipwrecks. It is home to an amazing abundance of wildlife – five per cent of the world\'s animal and plant species come from its varied terrain of volcanic mountains, tropical rainforests, deserts and shrubland. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3109597
